PLAY.TITLE: The History of Troilus and Cressida

PERSONAE.PERSONA: Margarelon, a bastard son of Priam
Calchas, a Trojan priest, taking part with the Greeks
Thersites, a deformed and scurrilous Greek
Cassandra, daughter to Priam, a prophetess

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THE PROLOGUE
SPEECH.LINE: In Troy, there lies the scene. From isles of Greece
The princes orgulous, their high blood chaf’d,
Have to the port of Athens sent their ships
Fraught with the ministers and instruments
Of cruel war. Sixty and nine, that wore
Their crownets regal, from th’ Athenian bay
Put forth toward Phrygia, and their vow is made
To ransack Troy, within whose strong immures
The ravish’d Helen, Menelaus’ queen,
With wanton Paris sleeps—and that’s the quarrel.
To Tenedos they come,
And the deep-drawing barks do there disgorge
Their warlike fraughtage. Now on Dardan plains
The fresh and yet unbruised Greeks do pitch
Their brave pavilions. Priam’s six-gated city,
Dardan and Timbria, Helias, Chetas, Troien,
And Antenorides, with massy staples
And corresponsive and fulfilling bolts
Sperr up the sons of Troy.
Now expectation, tickling skittish spirits,
On one and other side, Troyan and Greek,
Sets all on hazard—and hither am I come,
A prologue arm’d, but not in confidence
Of author’s pen or actor’s voice, but suited
In like conditions as our argument,
To tell you, fair beholders, that our play
Leaps o’er the vaunt and firstlings of those broils,
Beginning in the middle; starting thence away
To what may be digested in a play.
Like or find fault, do as your pleasures are,
Now good or bad, ’tis but the chance of war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Call here my varlet, I’ll unarm again.
Why should I war without the walls of Troy,
That find such cruel battle here within?
Each Troyan that is master of his heart,
Let him to field, Troilus, alas, hath none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Will this gear ne’er be mended?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: The Greeks are strong, and skillful to their strength,
Fierce to their skill, and to their fierceness valiant,
But I am weaker than a woman’s tear,
Tamer than sleep, fonder than ignorance,
Less valiant than the virgin in the night,
And skilless as unpractic’d infancy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I have told you enough of this. For my part, I’ll not meddle nor make no farther. He that will have a cake out of the wheat must tarry the grinding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Have I not tarried?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, the grinding; but you must tarry the bolting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Have I not tarried?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, the bolting; but you must tarry the leavening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Still have I tarried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, to the leavening, but here’s yet in the word “hereafter” the kneading, the making of the cake, the heating the oven, and the baking; nay, you must stay the cooling too, or ye may chance burn your lips.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Patience herself, what goddess e’er she be,
Doth lesser blench at suff’rance than I do.
At Priam’s royal table do I sit,
And when fair Cressid comes into my thoughts—
So, traitor, then she comes when she is thence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, she look’d yesternight fairer than ever
I saw her look, or any woman else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: I was about to tell thee—when my heart,
As wedged with a sigh, would rive in twain,
Lest Hector or my father should perceive me,
I have (as when the sun doth light a-scorn)
Buried this sigh in wrinkle of a smile,
But sorrow that is couch’d in seeming gladness
Is like that mirth fate turns to sudden sadness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: And her hair were not somewhat darker than Helen’s—well, go to!—there were no more comparison between the women! But for my part, she is my kinswoman; I would not, as they term it, praise her, but I would somebody had heard her talk yesterday as I did. I will not dispraise your sister Cassandra’s wit, but—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: O Pandarus! I tell thee, Pandarus—
When I do tell thee there my hopes lie drown’d,
Reply not in how many fathoms deep
They lie indrench’d. I tell thee I am mad
In Cressid’s love; thou answer’st she is fair,
Pourest in the open ulcer of my heart
Her eyes, her hair, her cheek, her gait, her voice,
Handiest in thy discourse, O, that her hand,
In whose comparison all whites are ink
Writing their own reproach; to whose soft seizure
The cygnet’s down is harsh, and spirit of sense
Hard as the palm of ploughman. This thou tell’st me,
As true thou tell’st me, when I say I love her,
But saying thus, in stead of oil and balm,
Thou lay’st in every gash that love hath given me
The knife that made it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: I speak no more than truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou dost not speak so much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, I’ll not meddle in it, let her be as she is; if she be fair, ’tis the better for her; and she be not, she has the mends in her own hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Pandarus! How now, Pandarus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: I have had my labor for my travail; ill thought on of her, and ill thought on of you; gone between and between, but small thanks for my labor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: What, art thou angry, Pandarus? What, with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Because she’s kin to me, therefore she’s not so fair as Helen. And she were not kin to me, she would be as fair a’ Friday as Helen is on Sunday. But what care I? I care not and she were a blackamoor, ’tis all one to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Say I she is not fair?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not care whether you do or no. She’s a fool to stay behind her father, let her to the Greeks; and so I’ll tell her the next time I see her. For my part, I’ll meddle nor make no more i’ th’ matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Pandarus—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Pandarus—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you speak no more to me, I will leave all as I found it, and there an end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, you ungracious clamors! Peace, rude sounds!
Fools on both sides, Helen must needs be fair,
When with your blood you daily paint her thus.
I cannot fight upon this argument;
It is too starv’d a subject for my sword.
But Pandarus—O gods! How do you plague me!
I cannot come to Cressid but by Pandar,
And he’s as teachy to be woo’d to woo,
As she is stubborn-chaste against all suit.
Tell me, Apollo, for thy Daphne’s love,
What Cressid is, what Pandar, and what we:
Her bed is India, there she lies, a pearl;
Between our Ilium and where she resides,
Let it be call’d the wild and wand’ring flood,
Ourself the merchant, and this sailing Pandar
Our doubtful hope, our convoy, and our bark.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, Prince Troilus, wherefore not a-field?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Because not there. This woman’s answer sorts,
For womanish it is to be from thence.
What news, Aeneas, from the field today?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: That Paris is returned home and hurt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: By whom, Aeneas?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Troilus, by Menelaus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Let Paris bleed, ’tis but a scar to scorn;
Paris is gor’d with Menelaus’ horn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Hark what good sport is out of town today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Better at home, if “would I might” were “may.”
But to the sport abroad—are you bound thither?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: In all swift haste.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Come go we then together.

SCENE.SCENEPERSONAE: (Cressida, Alexander, Pandarus, Aeneas, Antenor, Hector, Paris, Helenus, Troilus, Soldiers, Troilus’ Boy)
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Cressid and her man Alexander.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Who were those went by?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALEX.
SPEECH.LINE: Queen Hecuba and Helen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: And whither go they?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALEX.
SPEECH.LINE: Up to the eastern tower,
Whose height commands as subject all the vale,
To see the battle. Hector, whose patience
Is as a virtue fix’d, today was mov’d:
He chid Andromache and strook his armorer,
And like as there were husbandry in war,
Before the sun rose he was harness’d light,
And to the field goes he; where every flower
Did as a prophet weep what it foresaw
In Hector’s wrath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: What was his cause of anger?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALEX.
SPEECH.LINE: The noise goes, this: there is among the Greeks
A lord of Troyan blood, nephew to Hector,
They call him Ajax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Good; and what of him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALEX.
SPEECH.LINE: They say he is a very man per se and stands alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: So do all men, unless th’ are drunk, sick, or have no legs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALEX.
SPEECH.LINE: This man, lady, hath robb’d many beasts of their particular additions: he is as valiant as the lion, churlish as the bear, slow as the elephant; a man into whom nature hath so crowded humors that his valor is crush’d into folly, his folly sauc’d with discretion. There is no man hath a virtue that he hath not a glimpse of, nor any man an attaint but he carries some stain of it. He is melancholy without cause, and merry against the hair; he hath the joints of every thing, but every thing so out of joint that he is a gouty Briareus, many hands and no use, or purblind Argus, all eyes and no sight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: But how should this man, that makes me smile, make Hector angry?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALEX.
SPEECH.LINE: They say he yesterday cop’d Hector in the battle and strook him down, the disdain and shame whereof hath ever since kept Hector fasting and waking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Who comes here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALEX.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, your uncle Pandarus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Hector’s a gallant man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALEX.
SPEECH.LINE: As may be in the world, lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s that? What’s that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow, uncle Pandarus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow, cousin Cressid. What do you talk of? Good morrow, Alexander. How do you, cousin? When were you at Ilium?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: This morning, uncle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: What were you talking of when I came? Was Hector arm’d and gone ere ye came to Ilium? Helen was not up, was she?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Hector was gone, but Helen was not up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: E’en so; Hector was stirring early.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: That were we talking of, and of his anger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Was he angry?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: So he says here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: True, he was so; I know the cause too. He’ll lay about him today, I can tell them that, and there’s Troilus will not come far behind him. Let them take heed of Troilus; I can tell them that too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: What, is he angry too?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Who, Troilus? Troilus is the better man of the two.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: O Jupiter, there’s no comparison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: What, not between Troilus and Hector? Do you know a man if you see him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, if I ever saw him before and knew him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I say Troilus is Troilus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Then you say as I say, for I am sure he is not Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: No, nor Hector is not Troilus in some degrees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis just to each of them; he is himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Himself? Alas, poor Troilus, I would he were!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: So he is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Condition I had gone barefoot to India.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: He is not Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Himself? No! He’s not himself. Would ’a were himself! Well, the gods are above, time must friend or end. Well, Troilus, well, I would my heart were in her body. No, Hector is not a better man than Troilus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Excuse me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: He is elder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me, pardon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Th’ other’s not come to’t. You shall tell me another tale when th’ other’s come to’t. Hector shall not have his wit this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: He shall not need it if he have his own.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor his qualities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: No matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor his beauty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Twould not become him, his own’s better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: You have no judgment, niece. Helen herself swore th’ other day that Troilus, for a brown favor (for so ’tis, I must confess)—not brown neither—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: No, but brown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, to say truth, brown and not brown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: To say the truth, true and not true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: She prais’d his complexion above Paris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Paris hath color enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: So he has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Then Troilus should have too much: if she prais’d him above, his complexion is higher than his. He having color enough, and the other higher, is too flaming a praise for a good complexion. I had as lieve Helen’s golden tongue had commended Troilus for a copper nose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: I swear to you, I think Helen loves him better than Paris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Then she’s a merry Greek indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I am sure she does. She came to him th’ other day into the compass’d window—and you know he has not past three or four hairs on his chin—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed a tapster’s arithmetic may soon bring his particulars therein to a total.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, he is very young, and yet will he, within three pound, lift as much as his brother Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Is he so young a man and so old a lifter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: But to prove to you that Helen loves him: she came and puts me her white hand to his cloven chin—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Juno have mercy! How came it cloven?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, you know ’tis dimpled. I think his smiling becomes him better than any man in all Phrygia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: O, he smiles valiantly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Does he not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: O yes, and ’twere a cloud in autumn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, go to then. But to prove to you that Helen loves Troilus—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Troilus will stand to the proof, if You’ll prove it so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Troilus! Why, he esteems her no more than I esteem an addle egg.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: If you love an addle egg as well as you love an idle head, you would eat chickens i’ th’ shell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot choose but laugh to think how she tickled his chin. Indeed she has a marvell’s white hand, I must needs confess.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Without the rack.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: And she takes upon her to spy a white hair on his chin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, poor chin! Many a wart is richer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: But there was such laughing! Queen Hecuba laugh’d that her eyes ran o’er.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: With millstones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: And Cassandra laugh’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: But there was a more temperate fire under the pot of her eyes. Did her eyes run o’er too?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: And Hector laugh’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: At what was all this laughing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, at the white hair that Helen spied on Troilus’ chin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: And’t had been a green hair, I should have laugh’d too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: They laugh’d not so much at the hair as at his pretty answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: What was his answer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Quoth she, “Here’s but two and fifty hairs on your chin—and one of them is white.”

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: This is her question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s true, make no question of that. “Two and fifty hairs,” quoth he, “and one white. That white hair is my father, and all the rest are his sons.” “Jupiter,” quoth she, “which of these hairs is Paris my husband?” “The fork’d one,” quoth he, “pluck’t out, and give it him.” But there was such laughing! And Helen so blush’d, and Paris so chaf’d, and all the rest so laugh’d, that it pass’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: So let it now, for it has been a great while going by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, cousin, I told you a thing yesterday, think on’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: So I do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: I’ll be sworn ’tis true; he will weep you an’ ’twere a man born in April.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: And I’ll spring up in his tears an’ ’twere a nettle against May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Hark, they are coming from the field. Shall we stand up here and see them as they pass toward Ilion? Good niece, do, sweet niece Cressida.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: At your pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Here, here, here’s an excellent place, here we may see most bravely. I’ll tell you them all by their names as they pass by, but mark Troilus above the rest.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Aeneas and passes over the stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Speak not so loud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s Aeneas; is not that a brave man? He’s one of the flowers of Troy, I can tell you. But mark Troilus; you shall see anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Who’s that?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Antenor and passes over the stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s Antenor. He has a shrowd wit, I can tell you, and he’s man good enough. He’s one o’ th’ soundest judgments in Troy, whosoever, and a proper man of person. When comes Troilus? I’ll show you Troilus anon. If he see me, you shall see him nod at me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Will he give you the nod?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: You shall see.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: If he do, the rich shall have more.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Hector and passes over the stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s Hector, that, that, look you, that; there’s a fellow! Go thy way. Hector! There’s a brave man, niece. O brave Hector! Look how he looks! There’s a countenance! Is’t not a brave man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: O, a brave man!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Is ’a not? It does a man’s heart good. Look you what hacks are on his helmet! Look you yonder, do you see? Look you there, there’s no jesting; there’s laying on, take’t off who will, as they say. There be hacks!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Be those with swords?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Swords! Any thing, he cares not; and the devil come to him, it’s all one. By God’s lid, it does one’s heart good. Yonder comes Paris, yonder comes Paris.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Enter Paris and passes over the stage.
SPEECH.LINE: Look ye yonder, niece; is’t not a gallant man too, is’t not? Why, this is brave now. Who said he came hurt home today? He’s not hurt. Why, this will do Helen’s heart good now, ha? Would I could see Troilus now! You shall see Troilus anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Who’s that?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Helenus and passes over the stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s Helenus. I marvel where Troilus is. That’s Helenus. I think he went not forth today. That’s Helenus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Can Helenus fight, uncle?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Helenus? No. Yes, he’ll fight indifferent well. I marvel where Troilus is. Hark, do you not hear the people cry “Troilus”? Helenus is a priest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: What sneaking fellow comes yonder?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Troilus and passes over the stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Where? Yonder? That’s Deiphobus. ’Tis Troilus! There’s a man, niece! Hem! Brave Troilus, the prince of chivalry!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, for shame, peace!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Mark him, note him. O brave Troilus! Look well upon him, niece. Look you how his sword is bloodied, and his helm more hack’d than Hector’s, and how he looks, and how he goes! O admirable youth! He never saw three and twenty. Go thy way, Troilus, go thy way! Had I a sister were a grace, or a daughter a goddess, he should take his choice. O admirable man! Paris? Paris is dirt to him, and I warrant Helen, to change, would give an eye to boot.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Common Soldiers and pass over the stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Asses, fools, dolts! Chaff and bran, chaff and bran! Porridge after meat! I could live and die in the eyes of Troilus. Ne’er look, ne’er look, the eagles are gone; crows and daws, crows and daws! I had rather be such a man as Troilus than Agamemnon and all Greece.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: There is amongst the Greeks Achilles, a better man than Troilus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Achilles! A drayman, a porter, a very camel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well! Why, have you any discretion? Have you any eyes? Do you know what a man is? Is not birth, beauty, good shape, discourse, manhood, learning, gentleness, virtue, youth, liberality, and suchlike, the spice and salt that season a man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, a minc’d man, and then to be bak’d with no date in the pie, for then the man’s date is out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: You are such a woman, a man knows not at what ward you lie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Upon my back, to defend my belly, upon my wit, to defend my wiles, upon my secrecy, to defend mine honesty, my mask, to defend my beauty, and you, to defend all these; and at all these wards I lie, at a thousand watches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Say one of your watches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I’ll watch you for that; and that’s one of the chiefest of them too. If I cannot ward what I would not have hit, I can watch you for telling how I took the blow—unless it swell past hiding, and then it’s past watching.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: You are such another!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BOY.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, my lord would instantly speak with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Where?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BOY.
SPEECH.LINE: At your own house, there he unarms him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Good boy, tell him I come.
I doubt he be hurt. Fare ye well, good niece.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Adieu, uncle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: I will be with you, niece, by and by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: To bring, uncle?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, a token from Troilus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: By the same token, you are a bawd.
Words, vows, gifts, tears, and love’s full sacrifice,
He offers in another’s enterprise,
But more in Troilus thousandfold I see
Than in the glass of Pandar’s praise may be;
Yet hold I off. Women are angels, wooing:
Things won are done, joy’s soul lies in the doing.
That she belov’d knows nought that knows not this:
Men prize the thing ungain’d more than it is.
That she was never yet that ever knew
Love got so sweet as when desire did sue.
Therefore this maxim out of love I teach:
Achievement is command; ungain’d, beseech;
Then though my heart’s content firm love doth bear,
Nothing of that shall from mine eyes appear.

SCENE.SCENELOCATION: The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon’s tent.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Sennet. Enter Agamemnon, Nestor, Ulysses, Dio-Medes, Menelaus, with others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Princes:
What grief hath set these jaundies o’er your cheeks?
The ample proposition that hope makes
In all designs begun on earth below
Fails in the promis’d largeness. Checks and disasters
Grow in the veins of actions highest rear’d,
As knots, by the conflux of meeting sap,
Infects the sound pine, and diverts his grain
Tortive and errant from his course of growth.
Nor, princes, is it matter new to us
That we come short of our suppose so far
That after seven years’ siege yet Troy walls stand,
Sith every action that hath gone before,
Whereof we have record, trial did draw
Bias and thwart, not answering the aim
And that unbodied figure of the thought
That gave’t surmised shape. Why then, you princes,
Do you with cheeks abash’d behold our works,
And call them shames which are indeed nought else
But the protractive trials of great Jove
To find persistive constancy in men?
The fineness of which metal is not found
In fortune’s love; for then the bold and coward,
The wise and fool, the artist and unread,
The hard and soft, seem all affin’d and kin;
But in the wind and tempest of her frown,
Distinction, with a broad and powerful fan,
Puffing at all, winnows the light away,
And what hath mass or matter, by itself
Lies rich in virtue and unmingled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: With due observance of thy godlike seat,
Great Agamemnon, Nestor shall apply
Thy latest words. In the reproof of chance
Lies the true proof of men: the sea being smooth,
How many shallow bauble boats dare sail
Upon her patient breast, making their way
With those of nobler bulk!
But let the ruffian Boreas once enrage
The gentle Thetis, and anon behold
The strong-ribb’d bark through liquid mountains cut,
Bounding between the two moist elements,
Like Perseus’ horse. Where’s then the saucy boat
Whose weak untimber’d sides but even now
Corrivall’d greatness? Either to harbor fled,
Or made a toast for Neptune. Even so
Doth valor’s show and valor’s worth divide
In storms of fortune; for in her ray and brightness
The herd hath more annoyance by the breeze
Than by the tiger; but when the splitting wind
Makes flexible the knees of knotted oaks,
And flies fled under shade, why then the thing of courage,
As rous’d with rage, with rage doth sympathize,
And with an accent tun’d in self-same key
Retires to chiding fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Agamemnon,
Thou great commander, nerves and bone of Greece,
Heart of our numbers, soul and only sprite
In whom the tempers and the minds of all
Should be shut up, hear what Ulysses speaks.
Besides th’ applause and approbation
The which,
most mighty for thy place and sway,
And thou most reverend for thy stretch’d-out life,
I give to both your speeches, which were such
As Agamemnon and the hand of Greece
Should hold up high in brass, and such again
As venerable Nestor, hatch’d in silver,
Should with a bond of air strong as the axle-tree
On which heaven rides, knit all the Greekish ears
To his experienc’d tongue, yet let it please both,
Thou great, and wise, to hear Ulysses speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Speak, prince of Ithaca, and be’t of less expect
That matter needless, of importless burden,
Divide thy lips, than we are confident,
When rank Thersites opes his mastic jaws,
We shall hear music, wit, and oracle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Troy, yet upon his bases, had been down,
And the great Hector’s sword had lack’d a master,
But for these instances:
The specialty of rule hath been neglected,
And look how many Grecian tents do stand
Hollow upon this plain, so many hollow factions.
When that the general is not like the hive
To whom the foragers shall all repair,
What honey is expected? Degree being vizarded,
Th’ unworthiest shows as fairly in the mask.
The heavens themselves, the planets, and this centre
Observe degree, priority, and place,
Insisture, course, proportion, season, form,
Office, and custom, in all line of order;
And therefore is the glorious planet Sol
In noble eminence enthron’d and spher’d
Amidst the other; whose med’cinable eye
Corrects the ill aspects of planets evil,
And posts like the commandment of a king,
Sans check, to good and bad. But when the planets
In evil mixture to disorder wander,
What plagues and what portents, what mutiny!
What raging of the sea, shaking of earth!
Commotion in the winds!, frights, changes, horrors
Divert and crack, rend and deracinate
The unity and married calm of states
Quite from their fixure! O, when degree is shak’d,
Which is the ladder of all high designs,
The enterprise is sick. How could communities,
Degrees in schools, and brotherhoods in cities,
Peaceful commerce from dividable shores,
The primogenity and due of birth,
Prerogative of age, crowns, sceptres, laurels,
But by degree stand in authentic place?
Take but degree away, untune that string,
And hark what discord follows. Each thing meets
In mere oppugnancy: the bounded waters
Should lift their bosoms higher than the shores,
And make a sop of all this solid globe;
Strength should be lord of imbecility,
And the rude son should strike his father dead;
Force should be right, or rather, right and wrong
(Between whose endless jar justice resides)
Should lose their names, and so should justice too!
Then every thing include itself in power,
Power into will, will into appetite,
And appetite, an universal wolf
(So doubly seconded with will and power),
Must make perforce an universal prey,
And last eat up himself. Great Agamemnon,
This chaos, when degree is suffocate,
Follows the choking,
And this neglection of degree it is
That by a pace goes backward with a purpose
It hath to climb. The general’s disdain’d
By him one step below, he by the next,
That next by him beneath; so every step,
Exampled by the first pace that is sick
Of his superior, grows to an envious fever
Of pale and bloodless emulation,
And ’tis this fever that keeps Troy on foot,
Not her own sinews. To end a tale of length,
Troy in our weakness stands, not in her strength.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Most wisely hath Ulysses here discover’d
The fever whereof all our power is sick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: The nature of the sickness found, Ulysses,
What is the remedy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: The great Achilles, whom opinion crowns
The sinow and the forehand of our host,
Having his ear full of his airy fame,
Grows dainty of his worth, and in his tent
Lies mocking our designs. With him Patroclus
Upon a lazy bed the livelong day
Breaks scurril jests,
And with ridiculous and awkward action,
Which, slanderer, he imitation calls,
He pageants us. Sometime, great Agamemnon,
Thy topless deputation he puts on,
And like a strutting player, whose conceit
Lies in his hamstring, and doth think it rich
To hear the wooden dialogue and sound
’Twixt his stretch’d footing and the scaffoldage,
Such to-be-pitied and o’er-wrested seeming
He acts thy greatness in; and when he speaks,
’Tis like a chime a-mending, with terms unsquar’d,
Which from the tongue of roaring Typhon dropp’d
Would seem hyperboles. At this fusty stuff
The large Achilles, on his press’d bed lolling,
From his deep chest laughs out a loud applause,
Cries, “Excellent! ’tis Agamemnon right!
Now play me Nestor, hem, and stroke thy beard,
As he being dress’d to some oration.”
That’s done, as near as the extremest ends
Of parallels, as like as Vulcan and his wife;
Yet god Achilles still cries, “Excellent!
’Tis Nestor right. Now play him me, Patroclus,
Arming to answer in a night alarm.”
And then forsooth the faint defects of age
Must be the scene of mirth; to cough and spit,
And with a palsy fumbling on his gorget,
Shake in and out the rivet; and at this sport
Sir Valor dies; cries, “O, enough, Patroclus,
Or give me ribs of steel! I shall split all
In pleasure of my spleen.” And in this fashion,
All our abilities, gifts, natures, shapes,
Severals and generals of grace exact,
Achievements, plots, orders, preventions,
Excitements to the field, or speech for truce,
Success or loss, what is or is not, serves
As stuff for these two to make paradoxes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: And in the imitation of these twain—
Who, as Ulysses says, opinion crowns
With an imperial voice—many are infect.
Ajax is grown self-will’d, and bears his head
In such a rein, in full as proud a place
As broad Achilles; keeps his tent like him,
Makes factious feasts, rails on our state of war,
Bold as an oracle, and sets Thersites,
A slave whose gall coins slanders like a mint,
To match us in comparisons with dirt,
To weaken or discredit our exposure,
How rank soever rounded in with danger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: They tax our policy, and call it cowardice,
Count wisdom as no member of the war,
Forestall prescience, and esteem no act
But that of hand. The still and mental parts,
That do contrive how many hands shall strike
When fitness calls them on, and know by measure
Of their observant toil the enemies’ weight—
Why, this hath not a finger’s dignity.
They call this bed-work, mapp’ry, closet-war,
So that the ram that batters down the wall,
For the great swinge and rudeness of his poise,
They place before his hand that made the engine,
Or those that with the fineness of their souls
By reason guide his execution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Let this be granted, and Achilles’ horse
Makes many Thetis’ sons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: What trumpet? Look, Menelaus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MEN.
SPEECH.LINE: From Troy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: What would you ’fore our tent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this great Agamemnon’s tent, I pray you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Even this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: May one that is a herald and a prince
Do a fair message to his kingly eyes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: With surety stronger than Achilles’ arm,
’Fore all the Greekish heads, which with one voice
Call Agamemnon head and general.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Fair leave and large security. How may
A stranger to those most imperial looks
Know them from eyes of other mortals?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: How?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay,
I ask, that I might waken reverence,
And bid the cheek be ready with a blush
Modest as morning when she coldly eyes
The youthful Phoebus.
Which is that god in office, guiding men?
Which is the high and mighty Agamemnon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: This Troyan scorns us, or the men of Troy
Are ceremonious courtiers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Courtiers as free, as debonair, unarm’d,
As bending angels; that’s their fame in peace.
But when they would seem soldiers, they have galls,
Good arms, strong joints, true swords, and, great Jove’s accord,
Nothing so full of heart. But peace, Aeneas,
Peace, Troyan, lay thy finger on thy lips!
The worthiness of praise distains his worth,
If that the prais’d himself bring the praise forth;
But what the repining enemy commends,
That breath fame blows, that praise, sole pure, transcends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, you of Troy, call you yourself Aeneas?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, Greek, that is my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s your affairs, I pray you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, pardon, ’tis for Agamemnon’s ears.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: He hears nought privately that comes from Troy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I from Troy come not to whisper with him.
I bring a trumpet to awake his ear,
To set his sense on the attentive bent,
And then to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Speak frankly as the wind,
It is not Agamemnon’s sleeping hour.
That thou shalt know, Troyan, he is awake,
He tells thee so himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Trumpet, blow loud,
Send thy brass voice through all these lazy tents,
And every Greek of mettle, let him know,
What Troy means fairly shall be spoke aloud.
We have, great Agamemnon, here in Troy
A prince call’d Hector—Priam is his father—
Who in this dull and long-continued truce
Is resty grown. He bade me take a trumpet,
And to this purpose speak: kings, princes, lords!
If there be one among the fair’st of Greece
That holds his honor higher than his ease,
And seeks his praise more than he fears his peril,
That knows his valor, and knows not his fear,
That loves his mistress more than in confession
With truant vows to her own lips he loves,
And dare avow her beauty and her worth
In other arms than hers—to him this challenge!
Hector, in view of Troyans and of Greeks,
Shall make it good, or do his best to do it:
He hath a lady, wiser, fairer, truer,
Than ever Greek did couple in his arms,
And will tomorrow with his trumpet call,
Midway between your tents and walls of Troy,
To rouse a Grecian that is true in love.
If any come, Hector shall honor him;
If none, he’ll say in Troy when he retires,
The Grecian dames are sunburnt, and not worth
The splinter of a lance. Even so much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: This shall be told our lovers, Lord Aeneas.
If none of them have soul in such a kind,
We left them all at home. But we are soldiers,
And may that soldier a mere recreant prove,
That means not, hath not, or is not in love!
If then one is, or hath, or means to be,
That one meets Hector; if none else, I am he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell him of Nestor, one that was a man
When Hector’s grandsire suck’d. He is old now,
But if there be not in our Grecian mould
A noble man that hath no spark of fire
To answer for his love, tell him from me
I’ll hide my silver beard in a gold beaver,
And in my vambrace put my withered brawns,
And meeting him will tell him that my lady
Was fairer than his grandam, and as chaste
As may be in the world. His youth in flood,
I’ll prove this troth with my three drops of blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Now heavens forfend such scarcity of youth!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Fair Lord Aeneas, let me touch your hand;
To our pavilion shall I lead you, sir,
Achilles shall have word of this intent,
So shall each lord of Greece, from tent to tent.
Yourself shall feast with us before you go,
And find the welcome of a noble foe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Nestor!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: What says Ulysses?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: I have a young conception in my brain,
Be you my time to bring it to some shape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: What is’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: This ’tis:
Blunt wedges rive hard knots; the seeded pride
That hath to this maturity blown up
In rank Achilles must or now be cropp’d,
Or shedding, breed a nursery of like evil,
To overbulk us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, and how?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: This challenge that the gallant Hector sends,
However it is spread in general name,
Relates in purpose only to Achilles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: True, the purpose is perspicuous as substance,
Whose grossness little characters sum up;
And in the publication make no strain
But that Achilles, were his brain as barren
As banks of Libya (though, Apollo knows,
’Tis dry enough), will with great speed of judgment,
Ay, with celerity, find Hector’s purpose
Pointing on him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: And wake him to the answer, think you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, ’tis most meet; who may you else oppose
That can from Hector bring those honors off,
If not Achilles? Though’t be a sportful combat,
Yet in the trial much opinion dwells;
For here the Troyans taste our dear’st repute
With their fin’st palate; and trust to me, Ulysses,
Our imputation shall be oddly pois’d
In this vild action, for the success,
Although particular, shall give a scantling
Of good or bad unto the general,
And in such indexes (although small pricks
To their subsequent volumes) there is seen
The baby figure of the giant mass
Of things to come at large. It is suppos’d
He that meets Hector issues from our choice,
And choice (being mutual act of all our souls)
Makes merit her election, and doth boil
(As ’twere from forth us all) a man distill’d
Out of our virtues, who miscarrying,
What heart receives from hence a conquering part
To steel a strong opinion to themselves?
Which entertain’d, limbs are his instruments,
In no less working than are swords and bows
Directive by the limbs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Give pardon to my speech:
Therefore ’tis meet Achilles meet not Hector.
Let us like merchants first show foul wares,
And think perchance they’ll sell; if not,
The lustre of the better shall exceed
By showing the worse first. Do not consent
That ever Hector and Achilles meet,
For both our honor and our shame in this
Are dogg’d with two strange followers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: I see them not with my old eyes, what are they?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: What glory our Achilles shares from Hector,
Were he not proud, we all should share with him.
But he already is too insolent;
And it were better parch in Afric sun
Than in the pride and salt scorn of his eyes,
Should he scape Hector fair. If he were foil’d,
Why then we do our main opinion crush
In taint of our best man. No, make a lott’ry,
And by device let blockish Ajax draw
The sort to fight with Hector; among ourselves
Give him allowance for the better man,
For that will physic the great Myrmidon,
Who broils in loud applause, and make him fall
His crest that prouder than blue Iris bends.
If the dull brainless Ajax come safe off,
We’ll dress him up in voices; if he fail,
Yet go we under our opinion still
That we have better men. But hit or miss,
Our project’s life this shape of sense assumes:
Ajax employ’d plucks down Achilles’ plumes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, Ulysses, I begin to relish thy advice,
And I will give a taste thereof forthwith
To Agamemnon. Go we to him straight.
Two curs shall tame each other; pride alone
Must tarre the mastiffs on, as ’twere a bone.

SCENE.SCENELOCATION: A part of the Grecian camp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Thersites!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Agamemnon, how if he had biles—full, all over, generally?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Thersites!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: And those biles did run—say so—did not the general run then? Were not that a botchy core?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Dog!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Then would come some matter from him; I see none now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou bitch-wolf’s son, canst thou not hear? Feel then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: The plague of Greece upon thee, thou mongrel beef-witted lord!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Speak then, thou whinid’st leaven, speak; I will beat thee into handsomeness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: I shall sooner rail thee into wit and holiness, but I think thy horse will sooner con an oration without book than thou learn a prayer without book. Thou canst strike, canst thou? A red murrain a’ thy jade’s tricks!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Toadstool! Learn me the proclamation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Dost thou think I have no sense, thou strikest me thus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: The proclamation!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art proclaim’d fool, I think.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not, porpentine, do not, my fingers itch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: I would thou didst itch from head to foot; and I had the scratching of thee, I would make thee the loathsomest scab in Greece. When thou art forth in the incursions, thou strikest as slow as another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: I say, the proclamation!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou grumblest and railest every hour on Achilles, and thou art as full of envy at his greatness as Cerberus is at Proserpina’s beauty, ay, that thou bark’st at him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistress Thersites!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou shouldst strike him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Cobloaf!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: He would pun thee into shivers with his fist, as a sailor breaks a biscuit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: You whoreson cur!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Do! Do! Thou stool for a witch! Ay, do! Do! Thou sodden-witted lord! Thou hast no more brain than I have in mine elbows, an asinico may tutor thee. You scurvy valiant ass! Thou art here but to thrash Troyans, and thou art bought and sold among those of any wit, like a barbarian slave. If thou use to beat me, I will begin at thy heel, and tell what thou art by inches, thou thing of no bowels, thou!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: You dog!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: You scurvy lord!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: You cur!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Mars his idiot! Do, rudeness, do, camel, do, do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, how now, Ajax, wherefore do ye thus?
How now, Thersites, what’s the matter, man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: You see him there? Do you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, look upon him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: So I do. What’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but regard him well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Well? Why, so I do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: But yet you look not well upon him, for whosomever you take him to be, he is Ajax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: I know that, fool.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THEIR.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, but that fool knows not himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore I beat thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Lo, lo, lo, lo, what modicums of wit he utters! His evasions have ears thus long. I have bobb’d his brain more than he has beat my bones. I will buy nine sparrows for a penny, and his pia mater is not worth the ninth part of a sparrow. This lord, Achilles, Ajax, who wears his wit in his belly and his guts in his head, I’ll tell you what I say of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: What?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: I say, this Ajax—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, good Ajax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Has not so much wit—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I must hold you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: As will stop the eye of Helen’s needle, for whom he comes to fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, fool!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: I would have peace and quietness, but the fool will not—he there, that he! Look you there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: O thou damn’d cur! I shall—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you set your wit to a fool’s?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: No, I warrant you, the fool’s will shame it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Good words, Thersites.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s the quarrel?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: I bade the vile owl go learn me the tenor of the proclamation, and he rails upon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: I serve thee not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, go to, go to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: I serve here voluntary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Your last service was suff’rance, ’twas not voluntary; no man is beaten voluntary. Ajax was here the voluntary, and you as under an impress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: E’en so; a great deal of your wit, too, lies in your sinews, or else there be liars. Hector shall have a great catch, and ’a knock out either of your brains; ’a were as good crack a fusty nut with no kernel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: What, with me too, Thersites?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s Ulysses and old Nestor, whose wit was mouldy ere your grandsires had nails on their toes, yoke you like draught-oxen, and make you plough up the wars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: What? What?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, good sooth. To, Achilles! To, Ajax! To—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: I shall cut out your tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis no matter, I shall speak as much as thou afterwards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: No more words, Thersites, peace!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: I will hold my peace when Achilles’ brach bids me, shall I?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s for you, Patroclus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: I will see you hang’d like clatpoles ere I come any more to your tents. I will keep where there is wit stirring, and leave the faction of fools.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: A good riddance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, this, sir, is proclaim’d through all our host:
That Hector, by the fift hour of the sun,
Will with a trumpet ’twixt our tents and Troy
Tomorrow morning call some knight to arms
That hath a stomach, and such a one that dare
Maintain—I know not what, ’tis trash. Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell. Who shall answer him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not, ’tis put to lott’ry. Otherwise,
He knew his man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: O, meaning you? I will go learn more of it.

SCENE.SCENELOCATION: Troy. A room in Priam’s palace.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Priam, Hector, Troilus, Paris, and Helenus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRI.
SPEECH.LINE: After so many hours, lives, speeches spent,
Thus once again says Nestor from the Greeks;
“Deliver Helen, and all damage else—
As honor, loss of time, travail, expense,
Wounds, friends, and what else dear that is consum’d
In hot digestion of this cormorant war—
Shall be strook off.” Hector, what say you to’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Though no man lesser fears the Greeks than I
As far as toucheth my particular,
Yet, dread Priam,
There is no lady of more softer bowels,
More spungy to suck in the sense of fear,
More ready to cry out, “Who knows what follows?”
Than Hector is. The wound of peace is surety,
Surety secure, but modest doubt is call’d
The beacon of the wise, the tent that searches
To th’ bottom of the worst. Let Helen go.
Since the first sword was drawn about this question,
Every tithe soul, ’mongst many thousand dismes,
Hath been as dear as Helen; I mean, of ours.
If we have lost so many tenths of ours,
To guard a thing not ours nor worth to us
(Had it our name) the value of one ten,
What merit’s in that reason which denies
The yielding of her up?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, fie, my brother!
Weigh you the worth and honor of a king
So great as our dread father’s in a scale
Of common ounces? Will you with compters sum
The past-proportion of his infinite,
And buckle in a waist most fathomless
With spans and inches so diminutive
As fears and reasons? Fie, for godly shame!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HEL.
SPEECH.LINE: No marvel though you bite so sharp at reasons,
You are so empty of them. Should not our father
Bear the great sway of his affairs with reason,
Because your speech hath none that tell him so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: You are for dreams and slumbers, brother priest,
You fur your gloves with reason. Here are your reasons:
You know an enemy intends you harm;
You know a sword employ’d is perilous,
And reason flies the object of all harm.
Who marvels then, when Helenus beholds
A Grecian and his sword, if he do set
The very wings of reason to his heels
And fly like chidden Mercury from Jove,
Or like a star disorb’d? Nay, if we talk of reason,
Let’s shut our gates and sleep. Manhood and honor
Should have hare hearts, would they but fat their thoughts
With this cramm’d reason; reason and respect
Make livers pale and lustihood deject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Brother, she is not worth what she doth cost
The keeping.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s aught but as ’tis valued?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: But value dwells not in particular will,
It holds his estimate and dignity
As well wherein ’tis precious of itself
As in the prizer. ’Tis mad idolatry
To make the service greater than the god,
And the will dotes that is attributive
To what infectiously itself affects,
Without some image of th’ affected merit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: I take today a wife, and my election
Is led on in the conduct of my will,
My will enkindled by mine eyes and ears,
Two traded pilots ’twixt the dangerous shores
Of will and judgment: how may I avoid
(Although my will distaste what it elected)
The wife I chose? There can be no evasion
To blench from this and to stand firm by honor.
We turn not back the silks upon the merchant
When we have soil’d them, nor the remainder viands
We do not throw in unrespective sieve,
Because we now are full. It was thought meet
Paris should do some vengeance on the Greeks.
Your breath with full consent bellied his sails;
The seas and winds, old wranglers, took a truce,
And did him service; he touch’d the ports desir’d,
And for an old aunt whom the Greeks held captive,
He brought a Grecian queen, whose youth and freshness
Wrinkles Apollo’s, and makes pale the morning.
Why keep we her? The Grecians keep our aunt.
Is she worth keeping? Why, she is a pearl,
Whose price hath launched above a thousand ships,
And turn’d crown’d kings to merchants.
If You’ll avouch ’twas wisdom Paris went—
As you must needs, for you all cried “Go, go”—
If You’ll confess he brought home worthy prize—
As you must needs, for you all clapp’d your hands,
And cried “Inestimable!”—why do you now
The issue of your proper wisdoms rate,
And do a deed that never Fortune did,
Beggar the estimation which you priz’d
Richer than sea and land? O theft most base,
That we have stol’n what we do fear to keep!
But thieves unworthy of a thing so stol’n,
That in their country did them that disgrace
We fear to warrant in our native place!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAS.
SPEECH.LINE: Cry, Troyans, cry!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRI.
SPEECH.LINE: What noise? What shrike is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis our mad sister, I do know her voice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAS.
SPEECH.LINE: Cry, Troyans!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: It is Cassandra.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Cassandra raving with her hair about her ears.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAS.
SPEECH.LINE: Cry, Troyans, cry! Lend me ten thousand eyes,
And I will fill them with prophetic tears.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, sister, peace!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAS.
SPEECH.LINE: Virgins and boys, mid-age and wrinkled eld,
Soft infancy, that nothing canst but cry,
Add to my clamors! Let us pay betimes
A moi’ty of that mass of moan to come.
Cry, Troyans, cry! Practice your eyes with tears!
Troy must not be, nor goodly Ilion stand.
Our fire-brand brother Paris burns us all.
Cry, Troyans, cry! A Helen and a woe!
Cry, cry! Troy burns, or else let Helen go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, youthful Troilus, do not these high strains
Of divination in our sister work
Some touches of remorse? Or is your blood
So madly hot that no discourse of reason,
Nor fear of bad success in a bad cause,
Can qualify the same?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, brother Hector,
We may not think the justness of each act
Such and no other than event doth form it,
Nor once deject the courage of our minds
Because Cassandra’s mad. Her brain-sick raptures
Cannot distaste the goodness of a quarrel
Which hath our several honors all engag’d
To make it gracious. For my private part,
I am no more touch’d than all Priam’s sons;
And Jove forbid there should be done amongst us
Such things as might offend the weakest spleen
To fight for and maintain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: Else might the world convince of levity
As well my undertakings as your counsels,
But I attest the gods, your full consent
Gave wings to my propension, and cut off
All fears attending on so dire a project.
For what, alas, can these my single arms?
What propugnation is in one man’s valor
To stand the push and enmity of those
This quarrel would excite? Yet I protest,
Were I alone to pass the difficulties,
And had as ample power as I have will,
Paris should ne’er retract what he hath done,
Nor faint in the pursuit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRI.
SPEECH.LINE: Paris, you speak
Like one besotted on your sweet delights.
You have the honey still, but these the gall;
So to be valiant, is no praise at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I propose not merely to myself
The pleasures such a beauty brings with it,
But I would have the soil of her fair rape
Wip’d off, in honorable keeping her.
What treason were it to the ransack’d queen,
Disgrace to your great worths, and shame to me,
Now to deliver her possession up
On terms of base compulsion! Can it be
That so degenerate a strain as this
Should once set footing in your generous bosoms?
There’s not the meanest spirit on our party
Without a heart to dare, or sword to draw,
When Helen is defended; nor none so noble
Whose life were ill bestow’d, or death unfam’d,
Where Helen is the subject. Then I say,
Well may we fight for her whom we know well
The world’s large spaces cannot parallel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Paris and Troilus, you have both said well,
And on the cause and question now in hand
Have gloz’d, but superficially, not much
Unlike young men, whom Aristotle thought
Unfit to hear moral philosophy.
The reasons you allege do more conduce
To the hot passion of distemp’red blood
Than to make up a free determination
’Twixt right and wrong; for pleasure and revenge
Have ears more deaf than adders to the voice
Of any true decision. Nature craves
All dues be rend’red to their owners: now,
What nearer debt in all humanity
Than wife is to the husband? If this law
Of nature be corrupted through affection,
And that great minds, of partial indulgence
To their benumbed wills, resist the same,
There is a law in each well-order’d nation
To curb those raging appetites that are
Most disobedient and refractory.
If Helen then be wife to Sparta’s king,
As it is known she is, these moral laws
Of nature and of nations speak aloud
To have her back return’d. Thus to persist
In doing wrong extenuates not wrong,
But makes it much more heavy. Hector’s opinion
Is this in way of truth; yet ne’er the less,
My spritely brethren, I propend to you
In resolution to keep Helen still,
For ’tis a cause that hath no mean dependance
Upon our joint and several dignities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, there you touch’d the life of our design!
Were it not glory that we more affected
Than the performance of our heaving spleens,
I would not wish a drop of Troyan blood
Spent more in her defense. But, worthy Hector,
She is a theme of honor and renown,
A spur to valiant and magnanimous deeds,
Whose present courage may beat down our foes,
And fame in time to come canonize us,
For I presume brave Hector would not lose
So rich advantage of a promis’d glory
As smiles upon the forehead of this action
For the wide world’s revenue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: I am yours,
You valiant offspring of great Priamus.
I have a roisting challenge sent amongst
The dull and factious nobles of the Greeks
Will strike amazement to their drowsy spirits.
I was advertis’d their great general slept,
Whilst emulation in the army crept:
This I presume will wake him.

SCENE.SCENELOCATION: The Grecian camp. Before Achilles’ tent.
SCENE.SCENEPERSONAE: (Thersites, Patroclus, Achilles, Agamemnon, Ulysses, Nestor, Diomed, Ajax, Calchas)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, Thersites? What, lost in the labyrinth of thy fury? Shall the elephant Ajax carry it thus? He beats me, and I rail at him. O worthy satisfaction! Would it were otherwise: that I could beat him, whilst he rail’d at me. ’Sfoot, I’ll learn to conjure and raise devils, but I’ll see some issue of my spiteful execrations. Then there’s Achilles, a rare enginer! If Troy be not taken till these two undermine it, the walls will stand till they fall of themselves. O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus, forget that thou art Jove, the king of gods, and, Mercury, lose all the serpentine craft of thy caduceus, if ye take not that little little less than little wit from them that they have, which short-arm’d ignorance itself knows is so abundant scarce, it will not in circumvention deliver a fly from a spider, without drawing their massy irons and cutting the web! After this, the vengeance on the whole camp! Or rather, the Neapolitan bone-ache! For that methinks is the curse depending on those that war for a placket. I have said my prayers, and devil Envy say amen. What ho! My Lord Achilles!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Who’s there? Thersites? Good Thersites, come in and rail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: If I could ’a’ rememb’red a gilt counterfeit, thou wouldst not have slipp’d out of my contemplation. But it is no matter, thyself upon thyself! The common curse of mankind, folly and ignorance, be thine in great revenue! Heaven bless thee from a tutor, and discipline come not near thee! Lee thy blood be thy direction till thy death; then if she that lays thee out says thou art a fair corse, I’ll be sworn and sworn upon’t she never shrouded any but lazars. Amen.
Where’s Achilles?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: What, art thou devout? Wast thou in prayer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, the heavens hear me!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Who’s there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Thersites, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Where? Where? O, where? Art thou come? Why, my cheese, my digestion, why hast thou not serv’d thyself in to my table so many meals? Come, what’s Agamemnon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy commander, Achilles. Then tell me, Patroclus, what’s Achilles?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy lord, Thersites. Then tell me, I pray thee, what’s Thersites?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy knower, Patroclus. Then tell me, Patroclus, what art thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou must tell that knowest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: O, tell, tell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: I’ll decline the whole question: Agamemnon commands Achilles, Achilles is my lord, I am Patroclus’ knower, and Patroclus is a fool.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: You rascal!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, fool, I have not done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: He is a privileg’d man. Proceed, Thersites.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Agamemnon is a fool, Achilles is a fool, Thersites is a fool, and, as aforesaid, Patroclus is a fool.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Derive this; come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Agamemnon is a fool to offer to command Achilles, Achilles is a fool to be commanded of Agamemnon, Thersites is a fool to serve such a fool, and this Patroclus is a fool positive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Why am I a fool?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Make that demand of the prover, it suffices me thou art. Look you, who comes here?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Agamemnon, Ulysses, Nestor, Diomed, Ajax, and Calchas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, Patroclus, I’ll speak with nobody. Come in with me, Thersites.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Here is such patchery, such juggling, and such knavery! All the argument is a whore and a cuckold, a good quarrel to draw emulous factions and bleed to death upon. Now the dry suppeago on the subject, and war and lechery confound all!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is Achilles?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Within his tent, but ill dispos’d, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it be known to him that we are here.
He shent our messengers, and we lay by
Our appertainings, visiting of him.
Let him be told so, lest perchance he think
We dare not move the question of our place,
Or know not what we are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: I shall say so to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: We saw him at the opening of his tent,
He is not sick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, lion-sick, sick of proud heart. You may call it melancholy, if you will favor the man; but by my head, ’tis pride. But why, why? Let him show us a cause. A word, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: What moves Ajax thus to bay at him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Achilles hath inveigled his fool from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Who, Thersites?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: He.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Then will Ajax lack matter, if he have lost his argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: No, you see he is his argument that has his argument, Achilles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: All the better, their fraction is more our wish than their faction. But it was a strong composure a fool could disunite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: The amity that wisdom knits not, folly may easily untie.
Here comes Patroclus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: No Achilles with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: The elephant hath joints, but none for courtesy; his legs are legs for necessity, not for flexure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Achilles bids me say he is much sorry,
If any thing more than your sport and pleasure
Did move your greatness and this noble state
To call upon him. He hopes it is no other
But for your health and your disgestion sake,
An after-dinner’s breath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Hear you, Patroclus:
We are too well acquainted with these answers,
But his evasion, wing’d thus swift with scorn,
Cannot outfly our apprehensions.
Much attribute he hath, and much the reason
Why we ascribe it to him; yet all his virtues,
Not virtuously on his own part beheld,
Do in our eyes begin to lose their gloss,
Yea, like fair fruit in an unwholesome dish,
Are like to rot untasted. Go and tell him
We come to speak with him, and you shall not sin
If you do say we think him over-proud
And under-honest, in self-assumption greater
Than in the note of judgment; and worthier than himself
Here tend the savage strangeness he puts on,
Disguise the holy strength of their command,
And underwrite in an observing kind
His humorous predominance; yea, watch
His pettish lines, his ebbs, his flows, as if
The passage and whole carriage of this action
Rode on his tide. Go tell him this, and add,
That if he overhold his price so much,
We’ll none of him; but let him, like an engine
Not portable, lie under this report:
“Bring action hither, this cannot go to war.”
A stirring dwarf we do allowance give
Before a sleeping giant. Tell him so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: I shall, and bring his answer presently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: In second voice we’ll not be satisfied,
We come to speak with him. Ulysses, enter you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: What is he more than another?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: No more than what he thinks he is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Is he so much? Do you not think he thinks himself a better man than I am?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: No question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you subscribe his thought, and say he is?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: No, noble Ajax, you are as strong, as valiant, as wise, no less noble, much more gentle, and altogether more tractable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Why should a man be proud? How doth pride grow? I know not what pride is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Your mind is the clearer, Ajax, and your virtues the fairer. He that is proud eats up himself. Pride is his own glass, his own trumpet, his own chronicle, and whatever praises itself but in the deed, devours the deed in the praise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: I do hate a proud man, as I do hate the engend’ring of toads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: And yet he loves himself. Is’t not strange?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Achilles will not to the field tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s his excuse?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: He doth rely on none,
But carries on the stream of his dispose
Without observance or respect of any,
In will peculiar and in self-admission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Why will he not upon our fair request
Untent his person and share th’ air with us?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Things small as nothing, for request’s sake only,
He makes important. Possess’d he is with greatness,
And speaks not to himself but with a pride
That quarrels at self-breath. Imagin’d worth
Holds in his blood such swoll’n and hot discourse
That ’twixt his mental and his active parts
Kingdom’d Achilles in commotion rages,
And batters down himself. What should I say?
He is so plaguy proud that the death-tokens of it
Cry “No recovery.”

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Let Ajax go to him.
Dear lord, go you and greet him in his tent.
’Tis said he holds you well, and will be led
At your request a little from himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: O Agamemnon, let it not be so!
We’ll consecrate the steps that Ajax makes
When they go from Achilles. Shall the proud lord
That bastes his arrogance with his own seam,
And never suffers matter of the world
Enter his thoughts, save such as doth revolve
And ruminate himself, shall he be worshipp’d
Of that we hold an idol more than he?
No! This thrice worthy and right valiant lord
Shall not so stale his palm, nobly acquir’d,
Nor, by my will, assubjugate his merit,
As amply titled as Achilles’ is,
By going to Achilles.
That were to enlard his fat-already pride,
And add more coals to Cancer when he burns
With entertaining great Hyperion.
This lord go to him! Jupiter forbid,
And say in thunder, “Achilles go to him.”

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: O, this is well. He rubs the vein of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: And how his silence drinks up his applause!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: If I go to him, with my armed fist
I’ll pash him o’er the face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: O no, you shall not go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: And he be proud with me, I’ll pheese his pride.
Let me go to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Not for the worth that hangs upon our quarrel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: A paltry, insolent fellow!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: How he describes himself!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Can he not be sociable?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: The raven chides blackness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: I’ll let his humors blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: He will be the physician that should be the patient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: And all men were of my mind—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Wit would be out of fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: ’A should not bear it so, ’a should eat swords first. Shall pride carry it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: And ’twould, you’d carry half.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: ’A would have ten shares. I will knead him, I’ll make him supple. He’s not yet through warm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Force him with praises—pour in, pour in, his ambition is dry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, you feed too much on this dislike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Our noble general, do not do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: You must prepare to fight without Achilles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, ’tis this naming of him does him harm.
Here is a man—but ’tis before his face,
I will be silent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore should you so?
He is not emulous, as Achilles is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Know the whole world, he is as valiant—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: A whoreson dog, that shall palter with us thus!
Would he were a Troyan!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: What a vice were it in Ajax now—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: If he were proud—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Or covetous of praise—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, or surly borne—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Or strange, or self-affected!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Thank the heavens, lord, thou art of sweet composure.
Praise him that gat thee, she that gave thee suck;
Fam’d be thy tutor, and thy parts of nature
Thrice fam’d beyond, beyond all erudition;
But he that disciplin’d thine arms to fight,
Let Mars divide eternity in twain,
And give him half; and for thy vigor,
Bull-bearing Milo his addition yield
To sinowy Ajax. I will not praise thy wisdom,
Which like a bourn, a pale, a shore, confines
Thy spacious and dilated parts. Here’s Nestor,
Instructed by the antiquary times;
He must, he is, he cannot but be wise.
But pardon, father Nestor, were your days
As green as Ajax’, and your brain so temper’d,
You should not have the eminence of him,
But be as Ajax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I call you father?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, my good son.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Be rul’d by him, Lord Ajax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: There is no tarrying here, the hart Achilles
Keeps thicket. Please it our great general
To call together all his state of war.
Fresh kings are come to Troy; tomorrow
We must with all our main of power stand fast;
And here’s a lord—come knights from east to west,
And cull their flower, Ajax shall cope the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Go we to council. Let Achilles sleep:
Light boats sail swift, though greater hulks draw deep.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Music sounds within. Enter Pandarus and a Servant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Friend, you! Pray you a word. Do you not follow the young Lord Paris?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, sir, when he goes before me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: You depend upon him, I mean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I do depend upon the Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: You depend upon a notable gentleman; I must needs praise him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: The Lord be prais’d!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: You know me, do you not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, sir, superficially.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Friend, know me better, I am the Lord Pandarus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope I shall know your honor better!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: I do desire it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: You are in the state of grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Grace? Not so, friend, honor and lordship are my titles. What music is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: I do but partly know, sir, it is music in parts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Know you the musicians?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: Wholly, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Who play they to?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: To the hearers, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: At whose pleasure, friend?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: At mine, sir, and theirs that love music.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Command, I mean, friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: Who shall I command, sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Friend, we understand not one another; I am too courtly and thou too cunning. At whose request do these men play?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s to’t indeed, sir. Marry, sir, at the request of Paris my lord, who is there in person; with him, the mortal Venus, the heart-blood of beauty, love’s invisible soul.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Who? My cousin Cressida?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: No, sir, Helen. Could not you find out that by her attributes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: It should seem, fellow, thou hast not seen the Lady Cressid. I come to speak with Paris from the Prince Troilus. I will make a complimental assault upon him, for my business seethes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: Sodden business! There’s a stew’d phrase indeed!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Fair be to you, my lord, and to all this fair company! Fair desires, in all fair measure, fairly guide them! Especially to you, fair queen, fair thoughts be your fair pillow!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: Dear lord, you are full of fair words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: You speak your fair pleasure, sweet queen. Fair prince, here is good broken music.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: You have broke it, cousin; and by my life you shall make it whole again—you shall piece it out with a piece of your performance. Nell, he is full of harmony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly, lady, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: O sir—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Rude, in sooth, in good sooth, very rude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: Well said, my lord, well, you say so in fits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: I have business to my lord, dear queen. My lord, will you vouchsafe me a word?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, this shall not hedge us out, we’ll hear you sing, certainly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, sweet queen, you are pleasant with me. But marry thus, my lord: my dear lord and most esteem’d friend, your brother Troilus—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord Pandarus, honey-sweet lord—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Go to, sweet queen, go to—commends himself most affectionately to you—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: You shall not bob us out of our melody. If you do, our melancholy upon your head!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet queen, sweet queen, that’s a sweet queen—i’ faith—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: And to make a sweet lady sad is a sour offense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, that shall not serve your turn, that shall it not, in truth la! Nay, I care not for such words, no, no. And, my lord, he desires you, that if the King call for him at supper, you will make his excuse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord Pandarus—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: What says my sweet queen, my very very sweet queen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: What exploit’s in hand? Where sups he tonight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but, my lord—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: What says my sweet queen? My cousin will fall out with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: You must not know where he sups.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: I’ll lay my life, with my disposer Cressida.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no! No such matter, you are wide. Come, your disposer is sick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I’ll make ’s excuse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, good my lord. Why should you say Cressida? No, your poor disposer’s sick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: I spy!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: You spy? What do you spy?—Come, give me an instrument.—Now, sweet queen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, this is kindly done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: My niece is horribly in love with a thing you have, sweet queen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: She shall have it, my lord, if it be not my Lord Paris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: He? No! She’ll none of him. They two are twain.
