SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: Falling in, after falling out, may make them three.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, I’ll hear no more of this, I’ll sing you a song now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, ay, prithee now. By my troth, sweet lord, thou hast a fine forehead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, you may, you may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: Let thy song be love. This love will undo us all. O Cupid, Cupid, Cupid!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Love? Ay, that it shall, i’ faith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, good now, love, love, nothing but love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: In good troth, it begins so.
“Love, love, nothing but love, still love, still more!
For O, love’s bow
Shoots buck and doe.
The shaft confounds
Not that it wounds,
But tickles still the sore.
These lovers cry, O ho, they die!
Yet that which seems the wound to kill,
Doth turn O ho! To ha, ha, he!
So dying love lives still.
O ho! A while, but ha, ha, ha!
O ho! Groans out for ha, ha, ha!—hey ho!”

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: In love, i’ faith, to the very tip of the nose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: He eats nothing but doves, love, and that breeds hot blood, and hot blood begets hot thoughts, and hot thoughts beget hot deeds, and hot deeds is love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this the generation of love—hot blood, hot thoughts, and hot deeds? Why, they are vipers. Is love a generation of vipers? Sweet lord, who’s a-field today?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: Hector, Deiphobus, Helenus, Antenor, and all the gallantry of Troy. I would fain have arm’d today, but my Nell would not have it so. How chance my brother Troilus went not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: He hangs the lip at something. You know all, Lord Pandarus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I, honey-sweet queen. I long to hear how they sped today. You’ll remember your brother’s excuse?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: To a hair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, sweet queen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: Commend me to your niece.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: I will, sweet queen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: They’re come from the field. Let us to Priam’s hall
To greet the warriors. Sweet Helen, I must woo you
To help unarm our Hector. His stubborn buckles,
With these your white enchanting fingers touch’d,
Shall more obey than to the edge of steel,
Or force of Greekish sinews. You shall do more
Than all the island kings—disarm great Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HELEN.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Twill make us proud to be his servant, Paris!
Yea, what he shall receive of us in duty
Gives us more palm in beauty than we have,
Yea, overshines ourself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet, above thought I love thee!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, where’s thy master? At my cousin Cressida’s?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MAN.
SPEECH.LINE: No, sir, he stays for you to conduct him thither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: O, here he comes! How now, how now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirrah, walk off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Have you seen my cousin?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Pandarus, I stalk about her door,
Like to a strange soul upon the Stygian banks
Staying for waftage. O, be thou my Charon,
And give me swift transportance to these fields
Where I may wallow in the lily-beds
Propos’d for the deserver! O gentle Pandar,
From Cupid’s shoulder pluck his painted wings,
And fly with me to Cressid!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Walk here i’ th’ orchard, I’ll bring her straight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: I am giddy; expectation whirls me round;
Th’ imaginary relish is so sweet
That it enchants my sense; what will it be,
When that the wat’ry palates taste indeed
Love’s thrice-repured nectar? Death, I fear me,
Sounding destruction, or some joy too fine,
Too subtle, potent, tun’d too sharp in sweetness
For the capacity of my ruder powers.
I fear it much, and I do fear besides
That I shall lose distinction in my joys,
As doth a battle, when they charge on heaps
The enemy flying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: She’s making her ready, she’ll come straight. You must be witty now: she does so blush, and fetches her wind so short, as if she were fray’d with a spirit. I’ll fetch her. It is the prettiest villain, she fetches her breath as short as a new-ta’en sparrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Even such a passion doth embrace my bosom:
My heart beats thicker than a feverous pulse,
And all my powers do their bestowing lose,
Like vassalage at unawares encount’ring
The eye of majesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, what need you blush? Shame’s a baby. Here she is now, swear the oaths now to her that you have sworn to me.

What, are you gone again? You must be watch’d ere you be made tame, must you? Come your ways, come your ways; and you draw backward, we’ll put you i’ th’ fills. Why do you not speak to her? Come, draw this curtain, and let’s see your picture. Alas the day, how loath you are to offend daylight! And ’twere dark you’d close sooner. So, so, rub on and kiss the mistress. How now, a kiss in fee-farm? Build there, carpenter, the air is sweet. Nay, you shall fight your hearts out ere I part you—the falcon as the tercel, for all the ducks i’ th’ river. Go to, go to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: You have bereft me of all words, lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Words pay no debts, give her deeds; but she’ll bereave you a’ th’ deeds too, if she call your activity in question. What, billing again? Here’s “In witness whereof the parties interchangeably”—Come in, come in, I’ll go get a fire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you walk in, my lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: O Cressid, how often have I wish’d me thus!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Wish’d, my lord? The gods grant—O my lord!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: What should they grant? What makes this pretty abruption? What too curious dreg espies my sweet lady in the fountain of our love?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: More dregs than water, if my fears have eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Fears make devils of cherubins, they never see truly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Blind fear that seeing reason leads finds safer footing than blind reason stumbling without fear. To fear the worst oft cures the worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: O, let my lady apprehend no fear. In all Cupid’s pageant there is presented no monster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor nothing monstrous neither?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing but our undertakings, when we vow to weep seas, live in fire, eat rocks, tame tigers; thinking it harder for our mistress to devise imposition enough than for us to undergo any difficulty impos’d. This is the monstruosity in love, lady, that the will is infinite and the execution confin’d, that the desire is boundless and the act a slave to limit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: They say all lovers swear more performance than they are able, and yet reserve an ability that they never perform; vowing more than the perfection of ten, and discharging less than the tenth part of one. They that have the voice of lions and the act of hares, are they not monsters?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Are there such? Such are not we. Praise us as we are tasted, allow us as we prove. Our head shall go bare till merit crown it. No perfection in reversion shall have a praise in present; we will not name desert before his birth, and being born, his addition shall be humble. Few words to fair faith. Troilus shall be such to Cressid as what envy can say worst shall be a mock for his truth, and what truth can speak truest not truer than Troilus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you walk in, my lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: What, blushing still? Have you not done talking yet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, uncle, what folly I commit, I dedicate to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: I thank you for that; if my lord get a boy of you, You’ll give him me. Be true to my lord; if he flinch, chide me for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: You know now your hostages: your uncle’s word and my firm faith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I’ll give my word for her too. Our kindred, though they be long ere they be woo’d, they are constant being won. They are burs, I can tell you, they’ll stick where they are thrown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Boldness comes to me now, and brings me heart.
Prince Troilus, I have lov’d you night and day
For many weary months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Why was my Cressid then so hard to win?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Hard to seem won; but I was won, my lord,
With the first glance that ever—pardon me,
If I confess much, you will play the tyrant.
I love you now, but till now not so much
But I might master it. In faith I lie,
My thoughts were like unbridled children grown
Too headstrong for their mother. See, we fools!
Why have I blabb’d? Who shall be true to us,
When we are so unsecret to ourselves?
But though I lov’d you well, I woo’d you not,
And yet, good faith, I wish’d myself a man,
Or that we women had men’s privilege
Of speaking first. Sweet, bid me hold my tongue,
For in this rapture I shall surely speak
The thing I shall repent. See, see, your silence,
Cunning in dumbness, from my weakness draws
My very soul of counsel! Stop my mouth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: And shall, albeit sweet music issues thence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Pretty, i’ faith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, I do beseech you pardon me,
’Twas not my purpose thus to beg a kiss.
I am asham’d. O heavens, what have I done!
For this time will I take my leave, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Your leave, sweet Cressid!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Leave! And you take leave till tomorrow morning—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you content you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: What offends you, lady?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, mine own company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: You cannot shun yourself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me go and try.
I have a kind of self resides with you;
But an unkind self, that itself will leave
To be another’s fool. I would be gone.
Where is my wit? I know not what I speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Well know they what they speak that speak so wisely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Perchance, my lord, I show more craft than love,
And fell so roundly to a large confession,
To angle for your thoughts, but you are wise,
Or else you love not; for to be wise and love
Exceeds man’s might; that dwells with gods above.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: O that I thought it could be in a woman—
As, if it can, I will presume in you—
To feed for aye her lamp and flames of love,
To keep her constancy in plight and youth,
Outliving beauties outward, with a mind
That doth renew swifter than blood decays!
Or that persuasion could but thus convince me
That my integrity and truth to you
Might be affronted with the match and weight
Of such a winnowed purity in love!
How were I then uplifted! But alas,
I am as true as truth’s simplicity,
And simpler than the infancy of truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: In that I’ll war with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: O virtuous fight,
When right with right wars who shall be most right!
True swains in love shall in the world to come
Approve their truth by Troilus. When their rhymes,
Full of protest, of oath and big compare,
Wants similes, truth tir’d with iteration,
As true as steel, as plantage to the moon,
As sun to day, as turtle to her mate,
As iron to adamant, as earth to th’ centre,
Yet after all comparisons of truth
(As truth’s authentic author to be cited)
“As true as Troilus” shall crown up the verse,
And sanctify the numbers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Prophet may you be!
If I be false, or swerve a hair from truth,
When time is old and hath forgot itself,
When water-drops have worn the stones of Troy,
And blind oblivion swallow’d cities up,
And mighty states characterless are grated
To dusty nothing, yet let memory,
From false to false among false maids in love,
Upbraid my falsehood! When th’ have said as false
As air, as water, wind, or sandy earth,
As fox to lamb, or wolf to heifer’s calf,
Pard to the hind, or step-dame to her son,
Yea, let them say, to stick the heart of falsehood,
“As false as Cressid.”

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Go to, a bargain made, seal it, seal it, I’ll be the witness. Here I hold your hand, here my cousin’s. If ever you prove false one to another, since I have taken such pain to bring you together, let all pitiful goers-between be call’d to the world’s end after my name; call them all Pandars. Let all constant men be Troiluses, all false women Cressids, and all brokers-between Pandars! Say, amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen. Whereupon I will show you a chamber, which bed, because it shall not speak of your pretty encounters, press it to death. Away!
And Cupid grant all tongue-tied maidens here
Bed, chamber, Pandar to provide this gear!

SCENE.SCENELOCATION: The Grecian camp. Before Achilles’ tent.
SCENE.SCENEPERSONAE: (Ulysses, Diomed, Nestor, Agamemnon, Ajax, Menelaus, Calchas, Achilles, Patroclus, Thersites)
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Ulysses, Diomed, Nestor, Agamemnon, Ajax, Menelaus, and Calchas. Flourish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAL.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, princes, for the service I have done,
Th’ advantage of the time prompts me aloud
To call for recompense. Appear it to your mind,
That through the sight I bear in things to come,
I have abandon’d Troy, left my possession,
Incurr’d a traitor’s name, expos’d myself
From certain and possess’d conveniences
To doubtful fortunes, sequest’ring from me all
That time, acquaintance, custom, and condition
Made tame and most familiar to my nature;
And here, to do you service, am become
As new into the world, strange, unacquainted.
I do beseech you, as in way of taste,
To give me now a little benefit
Out of those many regist’red in promise,
Which you say live to come in my behalf.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: What wouldst thou of us, Troyan? Make demand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAL.
SPEECH.LINE: You have a Troyan prisoner call’d Antenor,
Yesterday took; Troy holds him very dear.
Oft have you (often have you thanks therefore)
Desir’d my Cressid in right great exchange,
Whom Troy hath still denied, but this Antenor,
I know, is such a wrest in their affairs
That their negotiations all must slack,
Wanting his manage, and they will almost
Give us a prince of blood, a son of Priam,
In change of him. Let him be sent, great princes,
And he shall buy my daughter; and her presence
Shall quite strike off all service I have done,
In most accepted pain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Let Diomedes bear him,
And bring us Cressid hither; Calchas shall have
What he requests of us. Good Diomed,
Furnish you fairly for this interchange;
Withal bring word if Hector will tomorrow
Be answered in his challenge: Ajax is ready.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: This shall I undertake, and ’tis a burden
Which I am proud to bear.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Achilles and Patroclus and stand in the door of their tent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Achilles stands i’ th’ entrance of his tent.
Please it our general pass strangely by him,
As if he were forgot, and, princes all,
Lay negligent and loose regard upon him.
I will come last; ’tis like he’ll question me
Why such unplausive eyes are bent, why turn’d on him?
If so, I have derision medicinable
To use between your strangeness and his pride,
Which his own will shall have desire to drink.
It may do good, pride hath no other glass
To show itself but pride; for supple knees
Feed arrogance and are the proud man’s fees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: We’ll execute your purpose, and put on
A form of strangeness as we pass along.
So do each lord, and either greet him not,
Or else disdainfully, which shall shake him more
Than if not look’d on. I will lead the way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: What comes the general to speak with me?
You know my mind, I’ll fight no more ’gainst Troy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: What says Achilles? Would he aught with us?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Would you, my lord, aught with the general?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: The better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Good day, good day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MEN.
SPEECH.LINE: How do you? How do you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: What, does the cuckold scorn me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, Patroclus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow, Ajax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, and good next day too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: What mean these fellows? Know they not Achilles?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: They pass by strangely. They were us’d to bend,
To send their smiles before them to Achilles,
To come as humbly as they us’d to creep
To holy altars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: What, am I poor of late?
’Tis certain, greatness, once fall’n out with fortune,
Must fall out with men too. What the declin’d is,
He shall as soon read in the eyes of others
As feel in his own fall; for men, like butterflies,
Show not their mealy wings but to the summer,
And not a man, for being simply man,
Hath any honor, but honor for those honors
That are without him, as place, riches, and favor—
Prizes of accident as oft as merit,
Which when they fall, as being slippery standers,
The love that lean’d on them as slippery too,
Doth one pluck down another, and together
Die in the fall. But ’tis not so with me,
Fortune and I are friends. I do enjoy
At ample point all that I did possess,
Save these men’s looks, who do methinks find out
Some thing not worth in me such rich beholding
As they have often given. Here is Ulysses,
I’ll interrupt his reading.
How now, Ulysses?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, great Thetis’ son!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: What are you reading?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: A strange fellow here
Writes me that man, how dearly ever parted,
How much in having, or without or in,
Cannot make boast to have that which he hath,
Nor feels not what he owes, but by reflection;
As when his virtues, aiming upon others,
Heat them, and they retort that heat again
To the first giver.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: This is not strange, Ulysses.
The beauty that is borne here in the face
The bearer knows not, but commends itself
To others’ eyes; nor doth the eye itself,
That most pure spirit of sense, behold itself,
Not going from itself; but eye to eye opposed,
Salutes each other with each other’s form;
For speculation turns not to itself,
Till it hath travell’d and is mirror’d there
Where it may see itself. This is not strange at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not strain at the position—
It is familiar—but at the author’s drift,
Who in his circumstance expressly proves
That no man is the lord of any thing,
Though in and of him there be much consisting,
Till he communicate his parts to others;
Nor doth he of himself know them for aught,
Till he behold them formed in th’ applause
Where th’ are extended; who like an arch reverb’rate
The voice again, or like a gate of steel,
Fronting the sun, receives and renders back
His figure and his heat. I was much rapt in this,
And apprehended here immediately
Th’ unknown Ajax.
Heavens, what a man is there! A very horse,
That has he knows not what. Nature, what things there are
Most abject in regard, and dear in use!
What things again most dear in the esteem,
And poor in worth! Now shall we see tomorrow—
An act that very chance doth throw upon him—
Ajax renown’d! O heavens, what some men do,
While some men leave to do!
How some men creep in skittish Fortune’s hall,
Whiles others play the idiots in her eyes!
How one man eats into another’s pride,
While pride is fasting in his wantonness!
To see these Grecian lords!—why, even already
They clap the lubber Ajax on the shoulder,
As if his foot were on brave Hector’s breast,
And great Troy shriking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: I do believe it, for they pass’d by me
As misers do by beggars, neither gave to me
Good word nor look. What, are my deeds forgot?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Time hath, my lord, a wallet at his back,
Wherein he puts alms for oblivion,
A great-siz’d monster of ingratitudes.
Those scraps are good deeds past, which are devour’d
As fast as they are made, forgot as soon
As done. Perseverance, dear my lord,
Keeps honor bright; to have done is to hang
Quite out of fashion, like a rusty mail
In monumental mock’ry. Take the instant way,
For honor travels in a strait so narrow,
Where one but goes abreast. Keep then the path,
For emulation hath a thousand sons
That one by one pursue. If you give way,
Or hedge aside from the direct forthright,
Like to an ent’red tide, they all rush by
And leave you hindmost;
Or like a gallant horse fall’n in first rank,
Lie there for pavement to the abject rear,
O’errun and trampled on. Then what they do in present,
Though less than yours in past, must o’ertop yours;
For Time is like a fashionable host
That slightly shakes his parting guest by th’ hand,
And with his arms outstretch’d as he would fly,
Grasps in the comer. The welcome ever smiles,
And farewell goes out sighing. Let not virtue seek
Remuneration for the thing it was;
For beauty, wit,
High birth, vigor of bone, desert in service,
Love, friendship, charity, are subjects all
To envious and calumniating Time.
One touch of nature makes the whole world kin,
That all with one consent praise new-born gawds,
Though they are made and moulded of things past,
And give to dust, that is a little gilt,
More laud than gilt o’erdusted.
The present eye praises the present object.
Then marvel not, thou great and complete man,
That all the Greeks begin to worship Ajax;
Since things in motion sooner catch the eye
Than what stirs not. The cry went once on thee,
And still it might, and yet it may again,
If thou wouldst not entomb thyself alive
And case thy reputation in thy tent,
Whose glorious deeds but in these fields of late
Made emulous missions ’mongst the gods themselves,
And drave great Mars to faction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Of this my privacy
I have strong reasons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: But ’gainst your privacy
The reasons are more potent and heroical.
’Tis known, Achilles, that you are in love
With one of Priam’s daughters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha? Known?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Is that a wonder?
The providence that’s in a watchful state
Knows almost every grain of Pluto’s gold,
Finds bottom in th’ uncomprehensive depth,
Keeps place with thought and almost, like the gods,
Do thoughts unveil in their dumb cradles.
There is a mystery (with whom relation
Durst never meddle) in the soul of state,
Which hath an operation more divine
Than breath or pen can give expressure to.
All the commerce that you have had with Troy
As perfectly is ours as yours, my lord,
And better would it fit Achilles much
To throw down Hector than Polyxena.
But it must grieve young Pyrrhus now at home,
When fame shall in our islands sound her trump,
And all the Greekish girls shall tripping sing,
“Great Hector’s sister did Achilles win,
But our great Ajax bravely beat down him.”
Farewell, my lord; I as your lover speak:
The fool slides o’er the ice that you should break.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: To this effect, Achilles, have I mov’d you.
A woman impudent and mannish grown
Is not more loath’d than an effeminate man
In time of action. I stand condemn’d for this;
They think my little stomach to the war,
And your great love to me, restrains you thus.
Sweet, rouse yourself, and the weak wanton Cupid
Shall from your neck unloose his amorous fold,
And like a dewdrop from the lion’s mane,
Be shook to air.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall Ajax fight with Hector?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, and perhaps receive much honor by him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: I see my reputation is at stake,
My fame is shrowdly gor’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: O then beware!
Those wounds heal ill that men do give themselves.
Omission to do what is necessary
Seals a commission to a blank of danger,
And danger like an ague subtly taints
Even then when they sit idly in the sun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Go call Thersites hither, sweet Patroclus.
I’ll send the fool to Ajax and desire him
T’ invite the Troyan lords after the combat
To see us here unarm’d. I have a woman’s longing,
An appetite that I am sick withal,
To see great Hector in his weeds of peace,
To talk with him, and to behold his visage,
Even to my full of view.
A labor sav’d!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: A wonder!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: What?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Ajax goes up and down the field, asking for himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: How so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: He must fight singly tomorrow with Hector, and is so prophetically proud of an heroical cudgelling that he raves in saying nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: How can that be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, ’a stalks up and down like a peacock—a stride and a stand; ruminates like an hostess that hath no arithmetic but her brain to set down her reckoning; bites his lip with a politic regard, as who should say there were wit in this head and ’twould out—and so there is; but it lies as coldly in him as fire in a flint, which will not show without knocking. The man’s undone forever, for if Hector break not his neck i’ th’ combat, he’ll break’t himself in vainglory. He knows not me. I said, “Good morrow, Ajax”; and he replies, “Thanks, Agamemnon.” What think you of this man that takes me for the general? He’s grown a very land-fish, languageless, a monster. A plague of opinion! A man may wear it on both sides, like a leather jerkin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou must be my ambassador to him, Thersites.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Who, I? Why, he’ll answer nobody; he professes not answering. Speaking is for beggars; he wears his tongue in ’s arms. I will put on his presence, let Patroclus make demands to me; you shall see the pageant of Ajax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: To him, Patroclus. Tell him I humbly desire the valiant Ajax to invite the most valorous Hector to come unarm’d to my tent, and to procure safe-conduct for his person of the magnanimous and most illustrious six-or-seven-times-honor’d captain-general of the army, Agamemnon, et cetera. Do this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Jove bless great Ajax!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Hum?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: I come from the worthy Achilles—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Who most humbly desires you to invite Hector to his tent—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Hum?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: And to procure safe-conduct from Agamemnon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Agamemnon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: What say you to’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: God buy you, with all my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Your answer, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: If tomorrow be a fair day, by aleven of the clock it will go one way or other. Howsoever, he shall pay for me ere he has me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Your answer, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Fare ye well, with all my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, but he is not in this tune, is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: No; but he’s out of tune thus. What music will be in him when Hector has knock’d out his brains, I know not; but I am sure none, unless the fiddler Apollo get his sinews to make catlings on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, thou shalt bear a letter to him straight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me bear another to his horse, for that’s the more capable creature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: My mind is troubled, like a fountain stirr’d,
And I myself see not the bottom of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Would the fountain of your mind were clear again, that I might water an ass at it! I had rather be a tick in a sheep than such a valiant ignorance.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter at one door Aeneas with a torch; at another, Paris, Deiphobus, Antenor, Diomed the Grecian, and others with torches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: See ho! Who is that there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DEI.
SPEECH.LINE: It is the Lord Aeneas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Is the Prince there in person?
Had I so good occasion to lie long
As you, Prince Paris, nothing but heavenly business
Should rob my bed-mate of my company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s my mind too. Good morrow, Lord Aeneas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: A valiant Greek, Aeneas, take his hand,
Witness the process of your speech, wherein
You told how Diomed, a whole week by days,
Did haunt you in the field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Health to you, valiant sir,
During all question of the gentle truce;
But when I meet you arm’d, as black defiance
As heart can think or courage execute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: The one and other Diomed embraces.
Our bloods are now in calm, and, so long, health!
But when contention and occasion meet,
By Jove I’ll play the hunter for thy life,
With all my force, pursuit, and policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: And thou shalt hunt a lion that will fly
With his face backward. In humane gentleness,
Welcome to Troy! Now, by Anchises’ life,
Welcome indeed! By Venus’ hand I swear,
No man alive can love in such a sort
The thing he means to kill, more excellently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: We sympathize. Jove, let Aeneas live,
If to my sword his fate be not the glory,
A thousand complete courses of the sun!
But in mine emulous honor let him die,
With every joint a wound, and that tomorrow!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: We know each other well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: We do, and long to know each other worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the most despiteful gentle greeting,
The noblest hateful love, that e’er I heard of.
What business, lord, so early?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: I was sent for to the King, but why, I know not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: His purpose meets you; ’twas to bring this Greek
To Calchas’ house, and there to render him,
For the enfreed Antenor, the fair Cressid.
Let’s have your company, or if you please,
Haste there before us. I constantly believe
(Or rather call my thought a certain knowledge)
My brother Troilus lodges there tonight.
Rouse him and give him note of our approach,
With the whole quality wherefore. I fear
We shall be much unwelcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: That I assure you.
Troilus had rather Troy were borne to Greece
Than Cressid borne from Troy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: There is no help.
The bitter disposition of the time
Will have it so. On, lord, we’ll follow you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow, all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: And tell me, noble Diomed—faith, tell me true,
Even in soul of sound good-fellowship—
Who, in your thoughts, deserves fair Helen best,
Myself, or Menelaus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Both alike.
He merits well to have her that doth seek her,
Not making any scruple of her soil,
With such a hell of pain and world of charge;
And you as well to keep her that defend her,
Not palating the taste of her dishonor,
With such a costly loss of wealth and friends.
He like a puling cuckold would drink up
The lees and dregs of a flat tamed piece;
You like a lecher out of whorish loins
Are pleas’d to breed out your inheritors.
Both merits pois’d, each weighs nor less nor more,
But he as he, the heavier for a whore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: You are too bitter to your country-woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: She’s bitter to her country. Hear me, Paris:
For every false drop in her bawdy veins,
A Grecian’s life hath sunk; for every scruple
Of her contaminated carrion weight,
A Troyan hath been slain. Since she could speak,
She hath not given so many good words breath
As for her Greeks and Troyans suff’red death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: Fair Diomed, you do as chapmen do,
Dispraise the thing that they desire to buy,
But we in silence hold this virtue well,
We’ll not commend what we intend to sell.
Here lies our way.

SCENE.SCENELOCATION: The same. Court of Pandarus’ house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Dear, trouble not yourself, the morn is cold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Then, sweet my lord, I’ll call mine uncle down,
He shall unbolt the gates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Trouble him not;
To bed, to bed. Sleep kill those pretty eyes,
And give as soft attachment to thy senses
As infants empty of all thought!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: I prithee now to bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you a-weary of me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: O Cressida! But that the busy day,
Wak’d by the lark, hath rous’d the ribald crows,
And dreaming night will hide our joys no longer,
I would not from thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Night hath been too brief.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Beshrew the witch! With venomous wights she stays
As tediously as hell, but flies the grasps of love
With wings more momentary-swift than thought.
You will catch cold and curse me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Prithee tarry,
You men will never tarry.
O foolish Cressid! I might have still held off,
And then you would have tarried. Hark, there’s one up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s all the doors open here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: It is your uncle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: A pestilence on him! Now will he be mocking.
I shall have such a life!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, how now, how go maidenheads?
Here, you maid! Where’s my cousin Cressid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Go hang yourself, you naughty mocking uncle!
You bring me to do—and then you flout me too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: To do what, to do what? Let her say what.
What have I brought you to do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, beshrew your heart, You’ll ne’er be good,
Nor suffer others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ha! Alas, poor wretch! A poor capocchia! Hast not slept tonight? Would he not, a naughty man, let it sleep? A bugbear take him!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Did not I tell you? Would he were knock’d i’ th’ head!
Who’s that at door? Good uncle, go and see.
My lord, come you again into my chamber.
You smile and mock me, as if I meant naughtily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ha!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, you are deceived, I think of no such thing.
How earnestly they knock! Pray you come in.
I would not for half Troy have you seen here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Who’s there? What’s the matter? Will you beat down the door? How now, what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow, lord, good morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Who’s there? My Lord Aeneas! By my troth,
I knew you not. What news with you so early?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not Prince Troilus here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Here? What should he do here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, he is here, my lord, do not deny him. It doth import him much to speak with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Is he here, say you? It’s more than I know, I’ll be sworn. For my own part, I came in late. What should he do here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Who!—nay then. Come, come, You’ll do him wrong ere you are ware. You’ll be so true to him, to be false to him. Do not you know of him, but yet go fetch him hither, go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, I scarce have leisure to salute you,
My matter is so rash. There is at hand
Paris your brother, and Deiphobus,
The Grecian Diomed, and our Antenor
Deliver’d to us; and for him forthwith,
Ere the first sacrifice, within this hour,
We must give up to Diomedes’ hand
The Lady Cressida.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it so concluded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: By Priam and the general state of Troy.
They are at hand and ready to effect it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: How my achievements mock me!
I will go meet them; and, my Lord Aeneas,
We met by chance, you did not find me here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Good, good, my lord, the secrets of neighbor Pandar
Have not more gift in taciturnity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Is’t possible? No sooner got but lost? The devil take Antenor! The young prince will go mad. A plague upon Antenor! I would they had broke ’s neck!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: How now? What’s the matter? Who was here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, ah!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Why sigh you so profoundly? Where’s my lord? Gone? Tell me, sweet uncle, what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Would I were as deep under the earth as I am above!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: O the gods! What’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray thee get thee in. Would thou hadst ne’er been born! I knew thou wouldest be his death. O poor gentleman! A plague upon Antenor!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Good uncle, I beseech you, on my knees I beseech you, what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou must be gone, wench, thou must be gone; thou art chang’d for Antenor. Thou must to thy father, and be gone from Troilus. ’Twill be his death, ’twill be his bane, he cannot bear it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: O you immortal gods! I will not go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou must.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not, uncle. I have forgot my father,
I know no touch of consanguinity;
No kin, no love, no blood, no soul so near me
As the sweet Troilus. O you gods divine,
Make Cressid’s name the very crown of falsehood,
If ever she leave Troilus! Time, force, and death,
Do to this body what extremes you can;
But the strong base and building of my love
Is as the very centre of the earth,
Drawing all things to it. I’ll go in and weep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Do, do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Tear my bright hair, and scratch my praised cheeks,
Crack my clear voice with sobs, and break my heart,
With sounding Troilus. I will not go from Troy.

SCENE.SCENELOCATION: The same. Street before Pandarus’ house.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Paris, Troilus, Aeneas, Deiphobus, Antenor, Diomedes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: It is great morning, and the hour prefix’d
For her delivery to this valiant Greek
Comes fast upon. Good my brother Troilus,
Tell you the lady what she is to do,
And haste her to the purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Walk into her house.
I’ll bring her to the Grecian presently;
And to his hand when I deliver her,
Think it an altar, and thy brother Troilus
A priest there off’ring to it his own heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: I know what ’tis to love,
And would, as I shall pity, I could help!
Please you walk in, my lords.

SCENE.SCENEPERSONAE: (Pandarus, Cressida, Troilus, Aeneas, Paris, Antenor, Deiphobus, Diomedes)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Be moderate, be moderate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Why tell you me of moderation?
The grief is fine, full, perfect, that I taste,
And violenteth in a sense as strong
As that which causeth it. How can I moderate it?
If I could temporize with my affections,
Or brew it to a weak and colder palate,
The like allayment could I give my grief:
My love admits no qualifying dross,
No more my grief, in such a precious loss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Here, here, here he comes. Ah, sweet ducks!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: O Troilus, Troilus!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: What a pair of spectacles is here! Let me embrace too. “O heart,” as the goodly saying is,
“O heart, heavy heart,
Why sigh’st thou without breaking?”
Where he answers again,
“Because thou canst not ease thy smart
By friendship nor by speaking.”
There was never a truer rhyme. Let us cast away nothing, for we may live to have need of such a verse. We see it, we see it. How now, lambs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Cressid, I love thee in so strain’d a purity
That the blest gods, as angry with my fancy,
More bright in zeal than the devotion which
Cold lips blow to their deities, take thee from me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Have the gods envy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, ay, ay, ay, ’tis too plain a case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: And is it true that I must go from Troy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: A hateful truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: What, and from Troilus too?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: From Troy and Troilus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: is’t possible?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: And suddenly, where injury of chance
Puts back leave-taking, justles roughly by
All time of pause, rudely beguiles our lips
Of all rejoindure, forcibly prevents
Our lock’d embrasures, strangles our dear vows
Even in the birth of our own laboring breath.
We two, that with so many thousand sighs
Did buy each other, must poorly sell ourselves
With the rude brevity and discharge of one.
Injurious time now with a robber’s haste
Crams his rich thiev’ry up, he knows not how.
As many farewells as be stars in heaven,
With distinct breath and consign’d kisses to them,
He fumbles up into a loose adieu;
And scants us with a single famish’d kiss,
Distasted with the salt of broken tears.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, is the lady ready?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Hark, you are call’d. Some say the Genius so
Cries “come” to him that instantly must die.
—Bid them have patience, she shall come anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Where are my tears? Rain, to lay this wind, or my heart will be blown up by th’ root.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: I must then to the Grecians?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: No remedy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: A woeful Cressid ’mongst the merry Greeks!
When shall we see again?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Hear me, love. Be thou but true of heart—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: I true? How now? What wicked deem is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, we must use expostulation kindly,
For it is parting from us.
I speak not “be thou true” as fearing thee,
For I will throw my glove to Death himself
That there is no maculation in thy heart;
But “be thou true” say I to fashion in
My sequent protestation: be thou true,
And I will see thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: O, you shall be expos’d, my lord, to dangers
As infinite as imminent! But I’ll be true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: And I’ll grow friend with danger. Wear this sleeve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: And you this glove. When shall I see you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: I will corrupt the Grecian sentinels,
To give thee nightly visitation.
But yet be true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: O heavens, “be true” again?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Hear why I speak it, love.
The Grecian youths are full of quality;
Their loving well compos’d with gift of nature,
Flowing and swelling o’er with arts and exercise.
How novelty may move, and parts with person,
Alas, a kind of godly jealousy
(Which I beseech you call a virtuous sin)
Makes me afeard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: O heavens, you love me not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Die I a villain then!
In this I do not call your faith in question
So mainly as my merit. I cannot sing,
Nor heel the high lavolt, nor sweeten talk,
Nor play at subtle games—fair virtues all,
To which the Grecians are most prompt and pregnant—
But I can tell that in each grace of these
There lurks a still and dumb-discoursive devil
That tempts most cunningly, but be not tempted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you think I will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: No,
But something may be done that we will not,
And sometimes we are devils to ourselves,
When we will tempt the frailty of our powers,
Presuming on their changeful potency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, good my lord!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Come kiss, and let us part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: Brother Troilus!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Good brother, come you hither,
And bring Aeneas and the Grecian with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, will you be true?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Who, I? Alas, it is my vice, my fault:
Whiles others fish with craft for great opinion,
I with great truth catch mere simplicity;
Whilst some with cunning gild their copper crowns,
With truth and plainness I do wear mine bare.
Fear not my truth: the moral of my wit
Is “plain and true”; there’s all the reach of it.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Enter Aeneas, Paris, Antenor, Deiphobus, and Diomedes.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, Sir Diomed! Here is the lady
Which for Antenor we deliver you.
At the port, lord, I’ll give her to thy hand,
And by the way possess thee what she is.
Entreat her fair, and, by my soul, fair Greek,
If e’er thou stand at mercy of my sword,
Name Cressid, and thy life shall be as safe
As Priam is in Ilion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Fair Lady Cressid,
So please you, save the thanks this prince expects.
The lustre in your eye, heaven in your cheek,
Pleads your fair usage, and to Diomed
You shall be mistress, and command him wholly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Grecian, thou dost not use me courteously,
To shame the seal of my petition to thee
In praising her. I tell thee, lord of Greece,
She is as far high-soaring o’er thy praises
As thou unworthy to be call’d her servant.
I charge thee use her well, even for my charge;
For by the dreadful Pluto, if thou dost not,
Though the great bulk Achilles be thy guard,
I’ll cut thy throat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: O, be not mov’d, Prince Troilus.
Let me be privileg’d by my place and message,
To be a speaker free. When I am hence,
I’ll answer to my lust, and know you, lord,
I’ll nothing do on charge. To her own worth
She shall be priz’d; but that you say, “Be’t so,”
I speak it in my spirit and honor, “No.”

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, to the port. I’ll tell thee, Diomed,
This brave shall oft make thee to hide thy head.
Lady, give me your hand, and as we walk,
To our own selves bend we our needful talk.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt Troilus, Cressida, and Diomedes. Sound trumpet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: Hark, Hector’s trumpet!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: How have we spent this morning!
The Prince must think me tardy and remiss,
That swore to ride before him to the field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAR.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis Troilus’ fault. Come, come, to field with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DEI.
SPEECH.LINE: Let us make ready straight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, with a bridegroom’s fresh alacrity
Let us address to tend on Hector’s heels.
The glory of our Troy doth this day lie
On his fair worth and single chivalry.

SCENE.SCENELOCATION: The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
SCENE.SCENEPERSONAE: (Ajax, Achilles, Patroclus, Agamemnon, Menelaus, Ulysses, Nestor, Diomed, Cressida, Hector, Paris, Aeneas, Helenus, Troilus, Attendants, Diomedes)
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Ajax armed, Achilles, Patroclus, Agamemnon, Menelaus, Ulysses, Nestor, etc.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Here art thou in appointment fresh and fair,
Anticipating time. With starting courage,
Give with thy trumpet a loud note to Troy,
Thou dreadful Ajax, that the appalled air
May pierce the head of the great combatant,
And hale him hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou, trumpet, there’s my purse.
Now crack thy lungs, and split thy brazen pipe.
Blow, villain, till thy sphered bias cheek
Outswell the colic of puff’d Aquilon;
Come, stretch thy chest, and let thy eyes spout blood;
Thou blowest for Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: No trumpet answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis but early days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not yond Diomed, with Calchas’ daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis he, I ken the manner of his gait,
He rises on the toe. That spirit of his
In aspiration lifts him from the earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this the Lady Cressid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Even she.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Most dearly welcome to the Greeks, sweet lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Our general doth salute you with a kiss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet is the kindness but particular,
’Twere better she were kiss’d in general.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: And very courtly counsel. I’ll begin.
So much for Nestor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: I’ll take that winter from your lips, fair lady;
Achilles bids you welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MEN.
SPEECH.LINE: I had good argument for kissing once.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: But that’s no argument for kissing now,
For thus popp’d Paris in his hardiment,
And parted thus you and your argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: O deadly gall, and theme of all our scorns,
For which we lose our heads to gild his horns!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: The first was Menelaus’ kiss, this, mine;
Patroclus kisses you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MEN.
SPEECH.LINE: O, this is trim!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Paris and I kiss evermore for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MEN.
SPEECH.LINE: I’ll have my kiss, sir. Lady, by your leave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: In kissing, do you render or receive?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Both take and give.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: I’ll make my match to live,
The kiss you take is better than you give;
Therefore no kiss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MEN.
SPEECH.LINE: I’ll give you boot, I’ll give you three for one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: You are an odd man, give even or give none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MEN.
SPEECH.LINE: An odd man, lady? Every man is odd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Paris is not, for you know ’tis true
That you are odd, and he is even with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MEN.
SPEECH.LINE: You fillip me a’ th’ head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: No, I’ll be sworn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: It were no match, your nail against his horn.
May I, sweet lady, beg a kiss of you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: You may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: I do desire it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, beg then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then for Venus’ sake, give me a kiss
When Helen is a maid again and his.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: I am your debtor, claim it when ’tis due.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Never’s my day, and then a kiss of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Lady, a word. I’ll bring you to your father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: A woman of quick sense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, fie upon her!
There’s language in her eye, her cheek, her lip,
Nay, her foot speaks; her wanton spirits look out
At every joint and motive of her body.
O, these encounterers, so glib of tongue,
That give a coasting welcome ere it comes,
And wide unclasp the tables of their thoughts
To every ticklish reader! Set them down
For sluttish spoils of opportunity,
And daughters of the game.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALL.
SPEECH.LINE: The Troyans’ trumpet.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter all of Troy: Hector armed, Paris, Aeneas, Helenus, Troilus, and Attendants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Yonder comes the troop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Hail, all the state of Greece! What shall be done
To him that victory commands? Or do you purpose
A victor shall be known? Will you the knights
Shall to the edge of all extremity
Pursue each other, or shall they be divided
By any voice or order of the field?
Hector bade ask.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Which way would Hector have it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: He cares not, he’ll obey conditions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis done like Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: But securely done,
A little proudly, and great deal misprising
The knight oppos’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: If not Achilles, sir,
What is your name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: If not Achilles, nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore Achilles, but what e’er, know this:
In the extremity of great and little,
Valor and pride excel themselves in Hector,
The one almost as infinite as all,
The other blank as nothing. Weigh him well,
And that which looks like pride is courtesy.
This Ajax is half made of Hector’s blood,
In love whereof, half Hector stays at home;
Half heart, half hand, half Hector comes to seek
This blended knight, half Troyan and half Greek.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: A maiden battle then? O, I perceive you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Here is Sir Diomed. Go, gentle knight,
Stand by our Ajax. As you and Lord Aeneas
Consent upon the order of their fight,
So be it, either to the uttermost,
Or else a breath. The combatants being kin
Half stints their strife before their strokes begin.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Ajax and Hector enter the lists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: They are oppos’d already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: What Troyan is that same that looks so heavy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: The youngest son of Priam, a true knight,
Not yet mature, yet matchless, firm of word,
Speaking in deeds, and deedless in his tongue,
Not soon provok’d, nor being provok’d soon calm’d;
His heart and hand both open and both free,
For what he has he gives, what thinks he shows,
Yet gives he not till judgment guide his bounty,
Nor dignifies an impare thought with breath;
Manly as Hector, but more dangerous,
For Hector in his blaze of wrath subscribes
To tender objects, but he in heat of action
Is more vindicative than jealous love.
They call him Troilus, and on him erect
A second hope, as fairly built as Hector.
Thus says Aeneas, one that knows the youth
Even to his inches, and with private soul
Did in great Ilion thus translate him to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: They are in action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, Ajax, hold thine own!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Hector, thou sleep’st,
Awake thee!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: His blows are well dispos’d. There, Ajax!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: You must no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Princes, enough, so please you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not warm yet, let us fight again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: As Hector pleases.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then will I no more.
Thou art, great lord, my father’s sister’s son,
A cousin-german to great Priam’s seed;
The obligation of our blood forbids
A gory emulation ’twixt us twain.
Were thy commixtion Greek and Troyan so
That thou couldst say, “This hand is Grecian all,
And this is Troyan; the sinews of this leg
All Greek, and this all Troy; my mother’s blood
Runs on the dexter cheek, and this sinister
Bounds in my father’s” : by Jove multipotent,
Thou shouldst not bear from me a Greekish member
Wherein my sword had not impressure made
Of our rank feud; but the just gods gainsay
That any drop thou borrow’dst from thy mother,
My sacred aunt, should by my mortal sword
Be drained! Let me embrace thee, Ajax.
By him that thunders, thou hast lusty arms!
Hector would have them fall upon him thus.
Cousin, all honor to thee!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: I thank thee, Hector.
Thou art too gentle and too free a man.
I came to kill thee, cousin, and bear hence
A great addition earned in thy death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Not Neoptolemus so mirable,
On whose bright crest Fame with her loud’st Oyes
Cries, “This is he,” could promise to himself
A thought of added honor torn from Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: There is expectance here from both the sides,
What further you will do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: We’ll answer it:
The issue is embracement. Ajax, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: If I might in entreaties find success,
As seld I have the chance, I would desire
My famous cousin to our Grecian tents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis Agamemnon’s wish, and great Achilles
Doth long to see unarm’d the valiant Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Aeneas, call my brother Troilus to me,
And signify this loving interview
To the expecters of our Troyan part;
Desire them home. Give me thy hand, my cousin.
I will go eat with thee and see your knights.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Agamemnon and the rest come forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Great Agamemnon comes to meet us here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: The worthiest of them tell me name by name;
But for Achilles, my own searching eyes
Shall find him by his large and portly size.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Worthy all arms! As welcome as to one
That would be rid of such an enemy.
But that’s no welcome. Understand more clear,
What’s past and what’s to come is strew’d with husks
And formless ruin of oblivion;
But in this extant moment, faith and troth,
Strain’d purely from all hollow bias-drawing,
Bids thee, with most divine integrity,
From heart of very heart, great Hector, welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: I thank thee, most imperious Agamemnon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: My well-fam’d lord of Troy, no less to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MEN.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me confirm my princely brother’s greeting:
You brace of warlike brothers, welcome hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Who must we answer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: The noble Menelaus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: O, you, my lord? By Mars his gauntlet, thanks!
Mock not that I affect th’ untraded oath,
Your quondam wife swears still by Venus’ glove.
She’s well, but bade me not commend her to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MEN.
SPEECH.LINE: Name her not now, sir, she’s a deadly theme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: O, pardon, I offend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: I have, thou gallant Troyan, seen thee oft,
Laboring for destiny, make cruel way
Through ranks of Greekish youth, and I have seen thee,
As hot as Perseus, spur thy Phrygian steed,
Despising many forfeits and subduements,
When thou hast hung thy advanced sword i’ th’ air,
Not letting it decline on the declined,
That I have said to some my standers-by
“Lo Jupiter is yonder, dealing life!”
And I have seen thee pause and take thy breath,
When that a ring of Greeks have hemm’d thee in,
Like an Olympian wrastling. This have I seen,
But this thy countenance, still lock’d in steel,
I never saw till now. I knew thy grandsire,
And once fought with him. He was a soldier good,
But, by great Mars, the captain of us all,
Never like thee. O, let an old man embrace thee,
And, worthy warrior, welcome to our tents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis the old Nestor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me embrace thee, good old chronicle,
That hast so long walk’d hand in hand with time.
Most reverend Nestor, I am glad to clasp thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: I would my arms could match thee in contention,
As they contend with thee in courtesy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: I would they could.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha!
By this white beard, I’d fight with thee tomorrow.
Well, welcome, welcome!—I have seen the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: I wonder now how yonder city stands
When we have here her base and pillar by us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: I know your favor, Lord Ulysses, well.
Ah, sir, there’s many a Greek and Troyan dead
Since first I saw yourself and Diomed
In Ilion, on your Greekish embassy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I foretold you then what would ensue.
My prophecy is but half his journey yet,
For yonder walls that pertly front your town,
Yon towers, whose wanton tops do buss the clouds,
Must kiss their own feet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: I must not believe you.
There they stand yet, and modestly I think
The fall of every Phrygian stone will cost
A drop of Grecian blood. The end crowns all,
And that old common arbitrator, Time,
Will one day end it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: So to him we leave it.
Most gentle and most valiant Hector, welcome!
After the general, I beseech you next
To feast with me and see me at my tent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: I shall forestall thee, Lord Ulysses, thou!
Now, Hector, I have fed mine eyes on thee;
I have with exact view perus’d thee, Hector,
And quoted joint by joint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this Achilles?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: I am Achilles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand fair, I pray thee, let me look on thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Behold thy fill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I have done already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art too brief. I will the second time,
As I would buy thee, view thee limb by limb.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: O, like a book of sport thou’lt read me o’er;
But there’s more in me than thou understand’st.
Why dost thou so oppress me with thine eye?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell me, you heavens, in which part of his body
Shall I destroy him—whether there, or there, or there?—
That I may give the local wound a name,
And make distinct the very breach whereout
Hector’s great spirit flew. Answer me, heavens!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: It would discredit the blest gods, proud man,
To answer such a question. Stand again.
Think’st thou to catch my life so pleasantly
As to prenominate in nice conjecture
Where thou wilt hit me dead?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: I tell thee, yea.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Wert thou an oracle to tell me so,
I’d not believe thee. Henceforth guard thee well,
For I’ll not kill thee there, nor there, nor there,
But by the forge that stithied Mars his helm,
I’ll kill thee every where, yea, o’er and o’er.
You wisest Grecians, pardon me this brag.
His insolence draws folly from my lips,
But I’ll endeavor deeds to match these words,
Or may I never—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not chafe thee, cousin,
And you, Achilles, let these threats alone,
Till accident or purpose bring you to’t.
You may have every day enough of Hector,
If you have stomach. The general state, I fear,
Can scarce entreat you to be odd with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you let us see you in the field;
We have had pelting wars since you refus’d
The Grecians’ cause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Dost thou entreat me, Hector?
Tomorrow do I meet thee, fell as death;
Tonight all friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy hand upon that match.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: First, all you peers of Greece, go to my tent;
There in the full convive we. Afterwards,
As Hector’s leisure and your bounties shall
Concur together, severally entreat him.
Beat loud the taborins, let the trumpets blow,
That this great soldier may his welcome know.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt all but Troilus and Ulysses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord Ulysses, tell me, I beseech you,
In what place of the field doth Calchas keep?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: At Menelaus’ tent, most princely Troilus.
There Diomed doth feast with him tonight,
Who neither looks upon the heaven nor earth,
But gives all gaze and bent of amorous view
On the fair Cressid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I, sweet lord, be bound to you so much,
After we part from Agamemnon’s tent,
To bring me thither?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: You shall command me, sir.
But gentle tell me, of what honor was
This Cressida in Troy? Had she no lover there
That wails her absence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: O, sir, to such as boasting show their scars
A mock is due. Will you walk on, my lord?
She was belov’d, she lov’d; she is, and doth:
But still sweet love is food for fortune’s tooth.

SCENE.SCENELOCATION: The Grecian camp. Before Achilles’ tent.
SCENE.SCENEPERSONAE: (Achilles, Patroclus, Thersites, Agamemnon, Hector, Troilus, Ajax, Ulysses, Nestor, Menelaus, Diomed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: I’ll heat his blood with Greekish wine tonight,
Which with my scimitar I’ll cool tomorrow.
Patroclus, let us feast him to the height.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes Thersites.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, thou core of envy?
Thou crusty batch of nature, what’s the news?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, thou picture of what thou seemest, and idol of idiot-worshippers, here’s a letter for thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: From whence, fragment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, thou full dish of fool, from Troy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Who keeps the tent now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: The surgeon’s box, or the patient’s wound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Well said, adversity! And what needs these tricks?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Prithee be silent, boy, I profit not by thy talk. Thou art said to be Achilles’ male varlot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Male varlot, you rogue! What’s that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, his masculine whore. Now the rotten diseases of the south, the guts-griping, ruptures, catarrhs, loads a’ gravel in the back, lethargies, cold palsies, raw eyes, dirt-rotten livers, whissing lungs, bladders full of imposthume, sciaticas, lime-kills i’ th’ palm, incurable bone-ache, and the rivell’d fee-simple of the tetter, take and take again such preposterous discoveries!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, thou damnable box of envy, thou, what means thou to curse thus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Do I curse thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, no, you ruinous butt, you whoreson indistinguishable cur, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: No? Why art thou then exasperate, thou idle immaterial skein of sleave-silk, thou green sarcenet flap for a sore eye, thou tossel of a prodigal’s purse, thou? Ah, how the poor world is pest’red with such water-flies, diminutives of nature!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PATR.
SPEECH.LINE: Out, gall!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Finch-egg!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: My sweet Patroclus, I am thwarted quite
From my great purpose in tomorrow’s battle.
Here is a letter from Queen Hecuba,
A token from her daughter, my fair love,
Both taxing me and gaging me to keep
An oath that I have sworn. I will not break it.
Fall Greeks, fail fame, honor or go or stay,
My major vow lies here; this I’ll obey.
Come, come, Thersites, help to trim my tent;
This night in banqueting must all be spent.
Away, Patroclus!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: With too much blood and too little brain, these two may run mad, but, if with too much brain and too little blood they do, I’ll be a curer of madmen. Here’s Agamemnon, an honest fellow enough, and one that loves quails, but he has not so much brain as ear-wax; and the goodly transformation of Jupiter there, his brother, the bull, the primitive statue and oblique memorial of cuckolds, a thrifty shoeing-horn in a chain, hanging at his brother’s leg—to what form but that he is, should wit larded with malice, and malice fac’d with wit, turn him to? To an ass, were nothing, he is both ass and ox; to an ox, were nothing, he is both ox and ass. To be a dog, a moile, a cat, a fitchook, a toad, a lezard, an owl, a puttock, or a herring without a roe, I would not care; but to be Menelaus, I would conspire against destiny. Ask me not what I would be if I were not Thersites, for I care not to be the louse of a lazar, so I were not Menelaus. Hey-day! Sprites and fires!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Agamemnon, Hector, Troilus, Ajax, Ulysses, Nestor, Menelaus, and Diomed, with lights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: We go wrong, we go wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: No, yonder ’tis,
There where we see the lights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: I trouble you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: No, not a whit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes himself to guide you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, brave Hector, welcome, princes all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: So now, fair Prince of Troy, I bid good night.
Ajax commands the guard to tend on you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Thanks and good night to the Greeks’ general.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MEN.
SPEECH.LINE: Good night, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Good night, sweet Lord Menelaus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet draught! “Sweet,” quoth ’a! Sweet sink, sweet sewer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Good night and welcome, both at once, to those
That go or tarry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Good night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Old Nestor tarries; and you too, Diomed,
Keep Hector company an hour or two.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot, lord, I have important business,
The tide whereof is now. Good night, great Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Give me your hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Follow his torch, he goes to Calchas’ tent.
I’ll keep you company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet sir, you honor me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: And so good night.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exit Diomedes, Ulysses and Troilus following.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, enter my tent.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt Achilles, Hector, Ajax, and Nestor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: That same Diomed’s a false-hearted rogue, a most unjust knave. I will no more trust him when he leers than I will a serpent when he hisses. He will spend his mouth and promise, like Brabbler the hound, but when he performs, astronomers foretell it: it is prodigious, there will come some change; the sun borrows of the moon when Diomed keeps his word. I will rather leave to see Hector than not to dog him. They say he keeps a Troyan drab, and uses the traitor Calchas’ tent. I’ll after—nothing but lechery! All incontinent varlots!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: What, are you up here, ho? Speak!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAL.
SPEECH.LINE: Who calls?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Diomed. Calchas, I think. Where’s your daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAL.
SPEECH.LINE: She comes to you.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Troilus and Ulysses at a distance; after them, Thersites.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand where the torch may not discover us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Cressid comes forth to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, my charge?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, my sweet guardian, hark, a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, so familiar?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: She will sing any man at first sight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: And any man may sing her, if he can take her cliff; she’s noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you remember?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Remember? Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but do then,
And let your mind be coupled with your words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: What shall she remember?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: List!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet honey Greek, tempt me no more to folly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Roguery!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: I’ll tell you what—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Fo, fo, come, tell a pin. You are forsworn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: In faith, I cannot. What would you have me do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: A juggling trick—to be secretly open.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: What did you swear you would bestow on me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: I prithee do not hold me to mine oath,
Bid me do any thing but that, sweet Greek.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Good night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Hold, patience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, Troyan?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Diomed—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, good night, I’ll be your fool no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy better must.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Hark a word in your ear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: O plague and madness!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: You are moved, Prince, let us depart, I pray,
Lest your displeasure should enlarge itself
To wrathful terms. This place is dangerous,
The time right deadly. I beseech you go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Behold, I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, good my lord, go off;
You flow to great distraction. Come, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: I prithee stay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: You have not patience, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you stay. By hell and all hell’s torments,
I will not speak a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: And so good night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but you part in anger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Doth that grieve thee?
O withered truth!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, my lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: By Jove
I will be patient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Guardian! Why, Greek!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Fo, fo, adieu, you palter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: In faith, I do not. Come hither once again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: You shake, my lord, at something; will you go?
You will break out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: She strokes his cheek.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, stay; by Jove I will not speak a word.
There is between my will and all offenses
A guard of patience. Stay a little while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: How the devil Luxury, with his fat rump and potato finger, tickles these together! Fry, lechery, fry!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: But will you then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: In faith I will lo, never trust me else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Give me some token for the surety of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: I’ll fetch you one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: You have sworn patience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Fear me not, my lord.
I will not be myself, nor have cognition
Of what I feel; I am all patience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Now the pledge, now, now, now!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Here, Diomed, keep this sleeve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: O beauty, where is thy faith?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: My lord—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: I will be patient, outwardly I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: You look upon that sleeve, behold it well.
He lov’d me—O false wench!—Give’t me again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Whose was’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: It is no matter now I ha’t again.
I will not meet with you tomorrow night.
I prithee, Diomed, visit me no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Now she sharpens. Well said, whetstone!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: I shall have it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: What, this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: O all you gods! O pretty, pretty pledge!
Thy master now lies thinking on his bed
Of thee and me, and sighs, and takes my glove,
And gives memorial dainty kisses to it,
As I kiss thee. Nay, do not snatch it from me.
He that takes that doth take my heart withal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: I had your heart before, this follows it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: I did swear patience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: You shall not have it, Diomed, faith, you shall not.
I’ll give you something else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: I will have this. Whose was it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: It is no matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, tell me whose it was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Twas one’s that lov’d me better than you will.
But now you have it, take it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Whose was it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: By all Diana’s waiting-women yond,
And by herself, I will not tell you whose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Tomorrow will I wear it on my helm,
And grieve his spirit that dares not challenge it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Wert thou the devil, and wor’st it on thy horn,
It should be challeng’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well, ’tis done, ’tis past. And yet it is not;
I will not keep my word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then farewell,
Thou never shalt mock Diomed again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: You shall not go. One cannot speak a word
But it straight starts you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not like this fooling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I, by Pluto; but that that likes not you pleases me best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: What, shall I come? The hour—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, come—O Jove!—do come.—I shall be plagued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell till then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRES.
SPEECH.LINE: Good night. I prithee come.
Troilus, farewell! One eye yet looks on thee,
But with my heart the other eye doth see.
Ah, poor our sex! This fault in us I find,
The error of our eye directs our mind.
What error leads must err; O then conclude,
Minds sway’d by eyes are full of turpitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: A proof of strength she could not publish more,
Unless she said, “My mind is now turn’d whore.”

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: All’s done, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: It is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Why stay we then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: To make a recordation to my soul
Of every syllable that here was spoke.
But if I tell how these two did co-act,
Shall I not lie in publishing a truth?
Sith yet there is a credence in my heart,
An esperance so obstinately strong,
That doth invert th’ attest of eyes and ears,
As if those organs had deceptious functions,
Created only to calumniate.
Was Cressid here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot conjure, Troyan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: She was not, sure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Most sure she was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, my negation hath no taste of madness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor mine, my lord; Cressid was here but now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it not be believ’d for womanhood!
Think we had mothers, do not give advantage
To stubborn critics, apt without a theme
