For depravation, to square the general sex
By Cressid’s rule. Rather think this not Cressid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: What hath she done, Prince, that can soil our mothers?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing at all, unless that this were she.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Will ’a swagger himself out on ’s own eyes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: This she? No, this is Diomed’s Cressida.
If beauty have a soul, this is not she;
If souls guide vows, if vows be sanctimonies,
If sanctimony be the gods’ delight,
If there be rule in unity itself,
This was not she. O madness of discourse,
That cause sets up with and against itself!
Bi-fold authority, where reason can revolt
Without perdition, and loss assume all reason
Without revolt. This is, and is not, Cressid!
Within my soul there doth conduce a fight
Of this strange nature, that a thing inseparate
Divides more wider than the sky and earth,
And yet the spacious breadth of this division
Admits no orifex for a point as subtle
As Ariachne’s broken woof to enter.
Instance, O instance, strong as Pluto’s gates,
Cressid is mine, tied with the bonds of heaven;
Instance, O instance, strong as heaven itself,
The bonds of heaven are slipp’d, dissolv’d, and loos’d,
And with another knot, five-finger-tied,
The fractions of her faith, orts of her love,
The fragments, scraps, the bits and greasy relics
Of her o’er-eaten faith, are given to Diomed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: May worthy Troilus be half attached
With that which here his passion doth express?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, Greek, and that shall be divulged well
In characters as red as Mars his heart
Inflam’d with Venus. Never did young man fancy
With so eternal and so fix’d a soul.
Hark, Greek: as much as I do Cressid love,
So much by weight hate I her Diomed.
That sleeve is mine that he’ll bear on his helm.
Were it a casque compos’d by Vulcan’s skill,
My sword should bite it. Not the dreadful spout
Which shipmen do the hurricano call,
Constring’d in mass by the almighty sun,
Shall dizzy with more clamor Neptune’s ear,
In his descent, than shall my prompted sword
Falling on Diomed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: He’ll tickle it for his concupy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: O Cressid! O false Cressid! False, false, false!
Let all untruths stand by thy stained name,
And they’ll seem glorious.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: O, contain yourself;
Your passion draws ears hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: I have been seeking you this hour, my lord.
Hector by this is arming him in Troy;
Ajax, your guard, stays to conduct you home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Have with you, Prince. My courteous lord, adieu.
Farewell, revolted fair! And, Diomed,
Stand fast, and wear a castle on thy head!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: I’ll bring you to the gates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Accept distracted thanks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Would I could meet that rogue Diomed! I would’croak like a raven, I would bode, I would bode. Patroclus will give me any thing for the intelligence of this whore. The parrot will not do more for an almond than he for a commodious drab. Lechery, lechery, still wars and lechery, nothing else holds fashion. A burning devil take them!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AND.
SPEECH.LINE: When was my lord so much ungently temper’d
To stop his ears against admonishment?
Unarm, unarm, and do not fight today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: You train me to offend you, get you in.
By all the everlasting gods, I’ll go!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AND.
SPEECH.LINE: My dreams will sure prove ominous to the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: No more, I say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAS.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is my brother Hector?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AND.
SPEECH.LINE: Here, sister, arm’d, and bloody in intent.
Consort with me in loud and dear petition,
Pursue we him on knees; for I have dreamt
Of bloody turbulence, and this whole night
Hath nothing been but shapes and forms of slaughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAS.
SPEECH.LINE: O, ’tis true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Ho! Bid my trumpet sound!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAS.
SPEECH.LINE: No notes of sally, for the heavens, sweet brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Be gone, I say, the gods have heard me swear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAS.
SPEECH.LINE: The gods are deaf to hot and peevish vows;
They are polluted off’rings, more abhorr’d
Than spotted livers in the sacrifice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AND.
SPEECH.LINE: O, be persuaded! Do not count it holy
To hurt by being just; it is as lawful,
For we would give much, to use violent thefts,
And rob in the behalf of charity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAS.
SPEECH.LINE: It is the purpose that makes strong the vow,
But vows to every purpose must not hold;
Unarm, sweet Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Hold you still, I say;
Mine honor keeps the weather of my fate.
Life every man holds dear, but the dear man
Holds honor far more precious-dear than life.
How now, young man, meanest thou to fight today?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AND.
SPEECH.LINE: Cassandra, call my father to persuade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: No, faith, young Troilus, doff thy harness, youth,
I am today i’ th’ vein of chivalry.
Let grow thy sinews till their knots be strong,
And tempt not yet the brushes of the war.
Unarm thee, go, and doubt thou not, brave boy,
I’ll stand today for thee and me and Troy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Brother, you have a vice of mercy in you,
Which better fits a lion than a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: What vice is that? Good Troilus, chide me for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: When many times the captive Grecian falls,
Even in the fan and wind of your fair sword,
You bid them rise and live.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: O, ’tis fair play.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Fool’s play, by heaven, Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: How now? How now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: For th’ love of all the gods,
Let’s leave the hermit pity with our mother,
And when we have our armors buckled on,
The venom’d vengeance ride upon our swords,
Spur them to ruthful work, rein them from ruth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, savage, fie!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Hector, then ’tis wars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Troilus, I would not have you fight today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Who should withhold me?
Not fate, obedience, nor the hand of Mars
Beck’ning with fiery truncheon my retire,
Not Priamus and Hecuba on knees,
Their eyes o’ergalled with recourse of tears,
Nor you, my brother, with your true sword drawn,
Oppos’d to hinder me, should stop my way,
But by my ruin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAS.
SPEECH.LINE: Lay hold upon him, Priam, hold him fast,
He is thy crutch. Now if thou lose thy stay,
Thou on him leaning, and all Troy on thee,
Fall all together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRI.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, Hector, come, go back.
Thy wife hath dreamt, thy mother hath had visions,
Cassandra doth foresee, and I myself
Am like a prophet suddenly enrapt
To tell thee that this day is ominous:
Therefore come back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Aeneas is a-field,
And I do stand engag’d to many Greeks,
Even in the faith of valor, to appear
This morning to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRI.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, but thou shalt not go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: I must not break my faith.
You know me dutiful, therefore, dear sir,
Let me not shame respect, but give me leave
To take that course by your consent and voice,
Which you do here forbid me, royal Priam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAS.
SPEECH.LINE: O Priam, yield not to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AND.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not, dear father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Andromache, I am offended with you,
Upon the love you bear me, get you in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: This foolish, dreaming, superstitious girl
Makes all these bodements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAS.
SPEECH.LINE: O, farewell, dear Hector.
Look how thou diest, look how thy eye turns pale.
Look how thy wounds do bleed at many vents,
Hark how Troy roars, how Hecuba cries out,
How poor Andromache shrills her dolors forth.
Behold, distraction, frenzy, and amazement,
Like witless antics, one another meet,
And all cry, Hector! Hector’s dead! O Hector!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAS.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell; yet soft: Hector, I take my leave.
Thou dost thyself and all our Troy deceive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: You are amaz’d, my liege, at her exclaim.
Go in and cheer the town. We’ll forth and fight,
Do deeds worth praise, and tell you them at night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRI.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, the gods with safety stand about thee!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt severally Priam and Hector. Alarum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: They are at it, hark! Proud Diomed, believe,
I come to lose my arm, or win my sleeve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you hear, my lord? Do you hear?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: What now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: Here’s a letter come from yond poor girl.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me read.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: A whoreson tisick, a whoreson rascally tisick so troubles me, and the foolish fortune of this girl, and what one thing, what another, that I shall leave you one a’ th’s days; and I have a rheum in mine eyes too, and such an ache in my bones, that unless a man were curs’d, I cannot tell what to think on’t. What says she there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Words, words, mere words, no matter from the heart;
Th’ effect doth operate another way.
Go, wind, to wind, there turn and change together.
My love with words and errors still she feeds,
But edifies another with her deeds.

SCENE.SCENELOCATION: Plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Now they are clapper-clawing one another; I’ll go look on. That dissembling abominable varlet, Diomed, has got that same scurvy doting foolish young knave’s sleeve of Troy there in his helm. I would fain see them meet, that that same young Troyan ass, that loves the whore there, might send that Greekish whoremasterly villain with the sleeve back to the dissembling luxurious drab, of a sleeveless arrant. A’ th’ t’ other side, the policy of those crafty swearing rascals, that stale old mouse-eaten dry cheese, Nestor, and that same dog-fox, Ulysses, is not prov’d worth a blackberry. They set me up, in policy, that mongril cur, Ajax, against that dog of as bad a kind, Achilles; and now is the cur Ajax prouder than the cur Achilles, and will not arm today; whereupon the Grecians began to proclaim barbarism, and policy grows into an ill opinion.
Soft, here comes sleeve and t’ other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Fly not, for shouldst thou take the river Styx,
I would swim after.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou dost miscall retire.
I do not fly, but advantageous care
Withdrew me from the odds of multitude.
Have at thee!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: Hold thy whore, Grecian!—now for thy whore, Troyan!—now the sleeve, now the sleeve!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: What art thou, Greek? Art thou for Hector’s match?
Art thou of blood and honor?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, I am a rascal, a scurvy railing knave, a very filthy rogue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: I do believe thee, live.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: God-a-mercy, that thou wilt believe me, but a plague break thy neck—for frighting me! What’s become of the wenching rogues? I think they have swallow’d one another. I would laugh at that miracle—yet in a sort lechery eats itself. I’ll seek them.

SCENE.SCENEPERSONAE: (Diomed, Servant, Agamemnon, Nestor, Ulysses, Ajax, Achilles)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Go, go, my servant, take thou Troilus’ horse,
Present the fair steed to my lady Cressid.
Fellow, commend my service to her beauty;
Tell her I have chastis’d the amorous Troyan,
And am her knight by proof.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO. SERV.
SPEECH.LINE: I go, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Renew, renew! The fierce Polydamas
Hath beat down Menon; bastard Margarelon
Hath Doreus prisoner,
And stands Colossus-wise, waving his beam,
Upon the pashed corses of the kings
Epistrophus and Cedius; Polyxenes is slain,
Amphimachus and Thoas deadly hurt,
Patroclus ta’en or slain, and Palamedes
Sore hurt and bruised. The dreadful Sagittary
Appalls our numbers. Haste we, Diomed,
To reinforcement, or we perish all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Go bear Patroclus’ body to Achilles,
And bid the snail-pac’d Ajax arm for shame.
There is a thousand Hectors in the field:
Now here he fights on Galathe his horse,
And there lacks work; anon he’s there afoot,
And there they fly or die, like scaling sculls
Before the belching whale; then is he yonder,
And there the strawy Greeks, ripe for his edge,
Fall down before him like a mower’s swath.
Here, there, and every where, he leaves and takes,
Dexterity so obeying appetite
That what he will he does, and does so much
That proof is call’d impossibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ULYSS.
SPEECH.LINE: O, courage, courage, princes! Great Achilles
Is arming, weeping, cursing, vowing vengeance.
Patroclus’ wounds have rous’d his drowsy blood,
Together with his mangled Myrmidons,
That noseless, handless, hack’d and chipp’d, come to him,
Crying on Hector. Ajax hath lost a friend,
And foams at mouth, and he is arm’d and at it,
Roaring for Troilus, who hath done today
Mad and fantastic execution,
Engaging and redeeming of himself
With such a careless force, and forceless care,
As if that luck, in very spite of cunning,
Bade him win all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Troilus, thou coward Troilus!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, there, there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: So, so, we draw together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is this Hector?
Come, come, thou boy-queller, show thy face,
Know what it is to meet Achilles angry.
Hector, where’s Hector? I will none but Hector.

SCENE.SCENEPERSONAE: (Ajax, Diomed, Troilus, Hector, Achilles, Greek knight)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Troilus, thou coward Troilus, show thy head!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Troilus, I say, where’s Troilus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: What wouldst thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: I would correct him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: Were I the general, thou shouldst have my office
Ere that correction. Troilus, I say, what, Troilus!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: O traitor Diomed! Turn thy false face, thou traitor,
And pay thy life thou owest me for my horse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, art thou there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: I’ll fight with him alone. Stand, Diomed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: He is my prize, I will not look upon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Come both you cogging Greeks, have at you both!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, Troilus? O, well fought, my youngest brother!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Now do I see thee, ha! Have at thee, Hector!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Pause if thou wilt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: I do disdain thy courtesy, proud Troyan.
Be happy that my arms are out of use;
My rest and negligence befriends thee now,
But thou anon shalt hear of me again;
Till when, go seek thy fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Fare thee well.
I would have been much more a fresher man,
Had I expected thee. How now, my brother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Ajax hath ta’en Aeneas! Shall it be?
No, by the flame of yonder glorious heaven,
He shall not carry him; I’ll be ta’en too,
Or bring him off. Fate, hear me what I say!
I reck not though I end my life today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand, stand, thou Greek, thou art a goodly mark.
No? Wilt thou not? I like thy armor well;
I’ll frush it and unlock the rivets all,
But I’ll be master of it.
Wilt thou not, beast, abide?
Why then fly on, I’ll hunt thee for thy hide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Come here about me, you my Myrmidons,
Mark what I say. Attend me where I wheel;
Strike not a stroke, but keep yourselves in breath,
And when I have the bloody Hector found,
Empale him with your weapons round about,
In fellest manner execute your arms.
Follow me, sirs, and my proceedings eye,
It is decreed Hector the great must die.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Thersites; Menelaus and Paris fighting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: The cuckold and the cuckold-maker are at it. Now, bull! Now, dog! ’Loo, Paris, ’loo! Now my double-henn’d Spartan! ’Loo, Paris, ’loo! The bull has the game, ware horns ho!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MAR.
SPEECH.LINE: Turn, slave, and fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: What art thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MAR.
SPEECH.LINE: A bastard son of Priam’s.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THER.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a bastard too, I love bastards. I am bastard begot, bastard instructed, bastard in mind, bastard in valor, in every thing illegitimate. One bear will not bite another, and wherefore should one bastard? Take heed, the quarrel’s most ominous to us. If the son of a whore fight for a whore, he tempts judgment. Farewell, bastard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MAR.
SPEECH.LINE: The devil take thee, coward!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: Most putrefied core, so fair without,
Thy goodly armor thus hath cost thy life.
Now is my day’s work done, I’ll take good breath.
Rest, sword, thou hast thy fill of blood and death.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Puts off his helmet and hangs his shield behind him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Look, Hector, how the sun begins to set,
How ugly night comes breathing at his heels;
Even with the vail and dark’ning of the sun,
To close the day up, Hector’s life is done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HECT.
SPEECH.LINE: I am unarm’d, forgo this vantage, Greek.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: Strike, fellows, strike, this is the man I seek.
So, Ilion, fall thou next! Come, Troy, sink down!
Here lies thy heart, thy sinews, and thy bone.
On, Myrmidons, and cry you all amain,
“Achilles hath the mighty Hector slain!”
Hark, a retire upon our Grecian part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MYR.
SPEECH.LINE: The Troyans’ trumpet sound the like, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ACHIL.
SPEECH.LINE: The dragon wing of night o’erspreads the earth,
And stickler-like the armies separates.
My half-supp’d sword that frankly would have fed,
Pleas’d with this dainty bait, thus goes to bed.
Come tie his body to my horse’s tail,
Along the field I will the Troyan trail.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Sound retreat. Shout. Enter Agamemnon, Ajax, Menelaus, Nestor, Diomed, and the rest, marching.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: Hark, hark, what shout is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NEST.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, drums!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOLDIERS.
SPEECH.LINE: Achilles! Achilles! Hector’s slain! Achilles!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: DIO.
SPEECH.LINE: The bruit is, Hector’s slain, and by Achilles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AJAX.
SPEECH.LINE: If it be so, yet bragless let it be,
Great Hector was as good a man as he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AGAM.
SPEECH.LINE: March patiently along; let one be sent
To pray Achilles see us at our tent.
If in his death the gods have us befriended,
Great Troy is ours, and our sharp wars are ended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand ho! Yet are we masters of the field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Never go home, here starve we out the night—
Hector is slain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALL.
SPEECH.LINE: Hector! The gods forbid!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: He’s dead, and at the murderer’s horse’s tail,
In beastly sort, dragg’d through the shameful field.
Frown on, you heavens, effect your rage with speed!
Sit, gods, upon your thrones, and smile at Troy!
I say at once, let your brief plagues be mercy,
And linger not our sure destructions on!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: AENE.
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, you do discomfort all the host.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: You understand me not that tell me so.
I do not speak of flight, of fear, of death,
But dare all imminence that gods and men
Address their dangers in. Hector is gone.
Who shall tell Priam so, or Hecuba?
Let him that will a screech owl aye be call’d
Go in to Troy and say there, “Hector’s dead!”
There is a word will Priam turn to stone,
Make wells and Niobes of the maids and wives,
Cold statues of the youth, and in a word,
Scare Troy out of itself. But march away.
Hector is dead; there is no more to say.
Stay yet. You vile abominable tents,
Thus proudly pight upon our Phrygian plains,
Let Titan rise as early as he dare,
I’ll through and through you! And, thou great-siz’d coward,
No space of earth shall sunder our two hates.
I’ll haunt thee like a wicked conscience still,
That mouldeth goblins swift as frenzy’s thoughts.
Strike a free march. To Troy with comfort go;
Hope of revenge shall hide our inward woe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: But hear you, hear you!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TRO.
SPEECH.LINE: Hence, broker, lackey!
Ignominy, shame
Pursue thy life, and live aye with thy name!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PAN.
SPEECH.LINE: A goodly medicine for my aching bones! O world, world, world! Thus is the poor agent despis’d! O traders and bawds, how earnestly are you set a-work, and how ill requited! Why should our endeavor be so lov’d and the performance so loath’d? What verse for it? What instance for it? Let me see:
Full merrily the humble-bee doth sing,
Till he hath lost his honey and his sting;
And being once subdu’d in armed tail,
Sweet honey and sweet notes together fail.
Good traders in the flesh, set this in your painted cloths:
As many as be here of Pandar’s hall,
Your eyes, half out, weep out at Pandar’s fall;
Or if you cannot weep, yet give some groans,
Though not for me, yet for your aching bones.
Brethren and sisters of the hold-door trade,
Some two months hence my will shall here be made.
It should be now, but that my fear is this,
Some galled goose of Winchester would hiss.
Till then I’ll sweat and seek about for eases,
And at that time bequeath you my diseases.
